Posted: February 22, 2015
												Half-Life Opposing Force is an expansion pack to Half-Life. You play as one of the marines that participates in the Black Mesa Incident (See Half-Life). Although the gameplay is not to different from Half-Life here are some of the things I liked and disliked.Pros:-A more detailed and immersive story (imo)-New types of enemies (Instead of reusing old enemies, although classics like headcrabs are present)-More different character models-New weapons with a mix of old weapons-Nice concept of commanding your own squad-Same fun gameplay as Half-Life-Less platforming sectionsCons:-Squad AI can be wierd some times (Like if you want an enginner to follow you through a door he will sometimes move to the door, and then walk away from you repeatedly)-Not enough medical / H.E.V supplies like the original Half-Life to help you out a bit-Underused mechanics like rope swing-No Half-Life 3Overall, Half-Life Opposing Force is very entertaining if you loved the original Half-Life than you will not be disappointed. (8.5/10)

content:
Posted: June 8, 2014
												Half-Life: Opposing Force is an excellent expansion for Valve's Half-Life. It gives you a whole new perspective in the game as you play as Adrian Shepard, a member of the military that you encounter as Gordon Freeman in Half-Life. Shepard is given unique firearms to the Half-Life universe, such as the sniper rifle and black hole gun, which were not present in Half-Life. Instead of a hazard course, there is a boot camp which runs the player through the usage of the PCV vest (the counterpart of the HEV suit used by Black Mesa scientists) and brand new weapons, such as the aforementioned sniper rifle with scope, and a modified pistol fitted with a laser sight. Teammates, such as a medic and an engineer, can be used to assist in combat situations by healing Shepard or breaking down locked doors in order to progress. New alien races are battled, and never-before-seen areas of the Black Mesa complex are explored, as well as areas from the original game. A new boss is also present at the end, with a moderately difficult way of defeating it.Gearbox really did an awesome job when making this expansion to the original Half-Life game.10/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 8, 2014
												If you've played the original Half-Life, liked it, and don't mind the good-for-1999 graphics, you'll also like Opposing Force.  It keeps the solid core gameplay from the original, but adds in new weapons, enemies, and puzzles - and they really are new puzzles, not just the old ones rearranged.  You'll also see your old nemeses - headcrabs, Vortigaunts, and the like.  A select few scenes from the original are revisited, but for the most part new areas of Black Mesa are explored.  Of particular note is that you can use more small alien specimens against your enemies than just the snarks from the original - and sometimes, this is necessary to succeed.If you haven't played the original Half-Life, you should probably start there, to get the background story for this one.  However, you could jump right in to Opposing Force without playing the original.  Just play the tutorial first, and you'll be okay.  Along the way, non-playable characters will fill you in on what's been going on.  Like the original, the gameplay mechanics are excellent in Opposing Force.  So if you're debating whether to get the original or try this one first at half the price, you can't really go wrong either way.I would consider Opposing Force to have lived up to the quality of the original.  It's shorter, but it's also less expensive, so I wouldn't consider that an issue.

Your platoon was among those that stormed Black Mesa after the Resonance Cascade failure. However, you were shot down by some of the alien aircraft and ended up being the sole survivor. You end up having to survive on your wits, a few disgruntled troops, a wisecracking Black Mesa guard, and a whole lot of weapons. I highly recommend this game, as it is part of my favorite series yet, and has a great storyline as well.~Fibcoa7P.S. I would highly suggest playing this in Easy mode unless you are extremely hardcore. Heres why. Half-life: Opposing Force is probably about 5 times harder than the normal Half-life games on Medium difficulty. Unless you want to be extremely frustrated, or are just REALLY good at Half-life, play this one on easy.

content:
Posted: September 30, 2015
Half-Life: Opposing Force is an expansion for the original Half-Life. This time you are Corporal Shepard, a soldier tasked with hunting down Gordon Freeman while fending of aliens at the same time. It soon turns out that in general chaos everyone fights everyone, including new alien species and black ops soldiers.There are a few new weapons (alien lightning gun, Desert Eagle) and some new features. You get to lead other soldiers with various specialties: engineer who can cut doors, medic who can heal you. You learn to climb ropes and at one point you can use alien technology of grappling gun.Graphics is not great, but it's cool enough and the level design with brilliant color schemes and lighting styles makes up for it.Music sets the mood nicely, especially dynamic themes when something serious is going down.It's 2015 and I definitely enjoyed playing Half-Life: Opposing Force!GAMEPLAY 8/10GRAPHICS 7/10AUDIO 8/10STORY 9/10

content:
Posted: July 22, 2016
												This is one of the finest FPS games I've ever played. While Blue Shift was decent at best, this game is downright excellent. It feels right at home for a Half-Life game and is not alienated in any way, shape or form. It has amazing attention to detail and references to the original game feel very natural rather than being forced in to remind you that it's a Half-Life game. The puzzles in the game are challenging enough to be fun, but not on a level like Portal where it makes it the whole focus of the game. I was able to enjoy the new characters just as I did in the original, but there are two flaws with this game. Sometimes absurdley powerful enemys cake the map like an 11 year old's Mario Maker level. The other flaw is that it lacks music in some intense scenes making them a little underwhelming. Nonetheless, it's definetly worth the play.

content:
Posted: July 2, 2016
												The first of 2 expansions to Half-Life 1. I'd say this one is my favorite.This one is about the length of Episode 2, but adds much more in terms of content value.Opposing Force adds several new weapons and a few new enemies. The Shockroach, M249, and M40A1 are great additions that really gave [the game] a new sense of life, and the Desert Eagle was a fun replacement to the Colt Python seen in the other Half-Life games.In terms of enemies, the Shock Trooper, Voltigore, and Pit Drones are very welcome additions to Xen's aliens, forming part of a new species simply named "Race X". They're more powerful than the Vortigaunts and Alien Grunts of the normal game, but are fascinating in their own right. However, Gearbox seems to be the main factor behind their creation, and I hope Valve could have them worked back into the main Half-Life franchise.Overall: A very fun and very deserving expansion into the Half-Life universe. It desperately needs a sequel, and I hope for the return of it's mechanics. 9/10

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 23, 2014
												This is how you make a good expansion pack.While the original Half Life puts you in the role of Gordon Freeman, Opposing Force puts you in the shoes of a conpletely different character during the events of the original game. Instead of being a scientist who is trying to fight for his life, you are now Adrian Shephard, A Corporal rank soldier who, alongside his platoon, has been sent to Black Mesa to clean up the problems that have occured there.And the mission goes to hell pretty damn fast.What was supposes to be a simple clean up mission for Adrian suddenly becomes a similar situation that Gordon had - a fight for survival. If Adrian must endure the madness of Black Mesa, he must adapt to his surroundings, use anything he can get his hands on, rely on those willing enough to help and use his military training plus his own wit to it's full potential. So far, Opposing Force does Half Life justice by sticking with a similar story with a lot of great ideas that contrast very well with it's predecessor, so that it doesn't become too similar.But what about the gameplay? Does it do justice to Half Life too? First off, due to the fact that you are now a Soldier instead of a Black Mesa Employee, there ane new friendly NPCs, who of which are Soldiers, Engineers, and Medics. All of which are a great help and can back each other up. And due to the way the story starts, you won't need to kill the survivors of Black Mesa (which was what the Military was sent for), the security guards and scientists of Black Mesa will still lend you a helping hand throughout the story. When it comes to weapons, sadly not all of the guns and gadgets that were in the original game make it back. However, all of the weapons that haven't made it back have been replaced with new and, surprisingly, BETTER weapons. Remember the Crowbar? You now have a stronger Combat Knife! How about the .357 Magnum? Now a Desert Eagle, which is faster and comes with a Laser sight! All the new weapons are not just replacements though, For instance, there is a new LMG weapon which is an absolute blast to use and feels completely different from the weapons that were in the original. Overall as far as weapons go, Opposing Force gives you more than just new and improved weapons. Heck I didn't even think the weapons needed to be replaced with better ones, seems what wasn't broken got fixed anyway. There are new Enemy NPC's too, and they fit very well into the Half Life Universe, such as a bigger zombie, Alien Shock Troopers and since the Military are on your side now, the enemy soldiers have been replaced with different Human enemies, I won't spoil who they are but they are a worthy replacement, seeing that they were also enemies of a different sort in the original game, now taking over another role. And the Level design is just as superb as the original, but with the inclusion of new weapons and NPCs, we get to see a load of new puzzles and situations that couldn't be done in the original game. Oh! and you can climb and swing on ropes now! Which adds to some cool things! So, as far as Gameplay goes, everything is better.Graphically, yeah I guess it is just as blocky and wooden as the original, but there are some really varied looking levels again, even the training level looks great! The new aliens look fearsome and formiddable. Again Half Life uses real time cutscenes, which is always a treat, not to mention they are well written.When it comes to audio again, the game sounds just as good as the original, the aliens sound angry, the guns are loud, the soundtrack is excellent and the voiceacting is superb. Soldiers now have different voice lines as well as a different voice actor  since they are now on your side, but they are a joy to hear... in a cheesy Star Fox sorta way. "MAN MY DOGS ARE BARKIN'!"But is there anything wrong with Half Life: Opposing Force? Sadly, there are a few issues. First off, the glitch that can get you stuck in the level terrain is still present, but again it doesn't happen very often. And... as much as I hate saying it, due to the fact you can get more teammates with more aggresive firepower, the remarkable AI from the original starts to show some of it's issues. For example, Sometimes, soldiers will not realise to stop shooting when the player is in their way of the enemy target, they'll even shoot if the player hasn't walked in the way and was already standing there, if I recall. Another little nitpick I have is that friendly Medics don't heal their own wounded teammates. However, the AI is still great, especially the enemy AI, as it's still relentless as it was in the original game. My last major gripe is the end boss, although was a bit challenging, I thought it was a bit too straight forward compared to the original.Tl;dr, Half Life: Opposing Force does justice to it's predecessor and is possibly one of the best Expansion packs I have ever had the joy of playing, and for an Expansion pack to add so much to an already perfect game is mesmarising. I may as well consider it a separate game from it's predecessor. Not only that, this was technically Gearbox Sofware's first ever project, and  considering how well made Opposing Force was, it was one hell of a way to start them off into the gaming industry. If you enjoyed Half Life, buy it. If you never played Half Life, buy it anyway!

content:
Posted: January 20, 2014
												Opposing Force was the only expansion pack to Half-Life that was really crtically acclaimed, and there's a good reason for that. To get this out of the way: this is a full game, not a short ripoff, and it remains Gearbox's best game to date in my opinion. Not only does it rival the original game, it remains a strong candidate for the best Half-Life game ever made. It's hard to believe that typically with an expansion pack, and the fact that was developed by another team just makes it even more unfathomable. However, Opposing Force gets everything right with Half-Life. Usually expansion packs don't end up being too special. They often do little else than add more content to a pre-existing game. Stand-alone expansions tend to fare better. Other examples of this type besides Opposing Force include Halo 3: ODST and Far Cry 3: Blood Dragon. Opposing Force doesn't screw up anything. The puzzle solving elements are still great. The platforming elements are still great. What it ultimately improves on besides just the visuals, and this is the main reason why it's so great, is combat and pacing. All of the new weapons are fun to use. There is not a single moment in this game that lacks tension or feels off, and in the end although it stands on its own it gets tied together with Half-Life very cohesively. This is what an expansion pack should be in a perfect world: something that goes beyond what it's expanding upon. And although most don't, this is an exception.

Posted: November 18, 2013
												One of my favorite FPS

Posted: November 19, 2010
												When Half-Life was released in 1998, nobody couldn't predict the real revolution the game started in the FPS World. As Doom, Half-Life was one of the best FPS in all times. So, an add-on was released in 1999, followed by a stand-alone, Blueshift, where you're playing Barney Calhoun, a security guard. Being in 2008, you already know what happened to Gordon and Barney. But what about the hero of Opposing Force?I'll refresh your mind about the three heroes of the first HL trilogy, set in the Black Mesa Era. Gordon Freeman is a scientist, working for a research center called Black Mesa and without willing it (the same can apply to the majority of his friends), triggered the opening of a portal leading to another world, called Xen. You're discovering that in reality, some scientists did know about Xen and that perhaps, it was planned to have an invasion. Gordon became the only hope for stopping it and having become a killing machine - for survival -, whether it was aliens, Marines or Black Ops, he was suited for the job. Barney Calhoun, a security guard, was working this day. Well, he did not know what or who started this bloody thing but he became an hero by fighting against the aliens and the Marines but only for a few survivors. He was also suited for some dangerous missions given by Professor Rosenberg in order to make work their only chance to escape the center. And finally, you have another hero, who fighted against aliens and Black Ops but who understood that killing guards or scientists wasn't a way for finding an exit to this hell.This hero, it's the corporal Adrian Shepard, USMC Marine, affected to the HECU unit, specialized in anormalous threats. He's sent to Black Mesa with one goal: kill Gordon Freeman. But his plane was ambushed by aliens. He's the only survivor of his unit. He have to find a way to reunite with others Marines. And when he finds one, well, he's trapped into Black Mesa. Now, it's a matter of survival and finding a way to escape, him, his friends, the scientists and the guards of Black Mesa. What happened to him after is currently unknown. Thanks to G-Man.Being a Marine, even if you have some common weapons found in Half-Life, like the shotgun or the MP5 grenade launcher, you have also the pleasure to see your weaponry increased with a Desert Eagle, a wrench (instead of the crowbar), a sniper rifle (instead of your trusty crossbow), a Barnacle (yep, it's a weapon now), an alien grenade launcher (Daddy's pet), the Displacer (allowing you to go to Xen), a chaingun, a Shocktrooper arm (instead of the Hornet Gun) and a knife. These additions are actually refreshing: Displacer have a good design, the alien grenade launcher and the Shocktrooper arm are fun to use and last but not least, if you love big chainguns making damage, well, you'll be happy.There are also new enemies or rather a new race: the Race-X, which is difficult to say if they're siding Xen's side or if they're battling against survivors (including Marines), Black Ops and Xen in the same time. You will fear the Pits Drones or the Voltigores (these ones are pretty difficult when being adults). As for the Shocktroopers, well, you will not really fear them but you'll be jealous to see their weapons with unlimited ammo when yours is limited to ten electricity discharges. For the Giant Worm and the final boss, well, as usual, you need to figure a plan to take them out because your weapons had no effect on them. As for the Black Ops, if the female version is still present (you know, the fast women in black), the male version is making an appearance: he has heavier weapons, making him slower than his counterpart but that also means that he can inflict more damage.That means also new allies: your fellow guys, medic, engineer, soldier but also what the first Marines in Black Mesa were ordered to kill: scientists and guards. Now, it's a matter of cooperation.You'll perhaps recognize some places (Black Mesa Inbound, you know, your trip in the tramway at the beginning of Half-Life or Lambda Core) but you'll discover others facilities. And shoking truths.Graphics are still good, despite having more than 10 years of age. Even if it's sometimes angular, you find pleasure to making your way in this environment.Soundtrack is also as good as HL's. Yes, it's more a military tune but don't forget that you're in the skin of a Marine. I loved the music before fighting the final boss, it was so intense and non-military that it's still one of my favorites tracks for Half-Life.You don't have the flashlight but you've an infrared vision but sometimes it's not practical, especially when you're in Foxtrot Uniform, in the sewers, fighting against adult Voltigores.Gameplay is still the same, yep, but why change it? I mean, it's a good one, so, I don't see the point to develop new things. As for Xen, I'm disappointed to see that the world itself doesn't give some of its secrets, like in Half-Life or in Blueshift (following Opposing Force).

Posted: August 10, 2015
												Half-Life: Opposing Force is the first of two standalone expansion packs developed by Gearbox for Half-Life. The first thing to know is that neither one is a continuation of Gordon Freeman's story. Instead, each is a look at the Black Mesa Incident from a different perspective. In Opposing Force, you play as Cpl. Adrian Shephard, one of the marines sent in to contain the catastrophe. You'll be moving through some of the same areas as Freeman, but the game is laudable in that while every area feels familiar, you'll rarely feel as if you're running over the same old ground.So, how's the story? Well, like Half-Life, the story is that you're attempting to escape Black Mesa. Cpl. Shephard is one of the first wave of marines sent in, and your transport is shot down immediately. The unit is thrown into complete chaos, and no one has any idea what they're doing. After all, while you might remember the marines from Half-Life as murderous enemies hellbent on killing everything in Black Mesa, Shephard's unit is lost before they can receive that order. Shephard is simply trying to escape, but like Freeman, he'll have an alien threat of his own to deal with. He also has more help than Freeman. While in Half-Life, you had security guards and scientists to aid you in different ways, he also has help from the scattered remnants of the military, namely medics, who heal you like scientists but more so, and engineers, who can cut locked doors open.  The weapon roster has been expanded as well. While Shephard doesn't have access to the Gluon Gun or the Tau Cannon, he has a number of new weapons to make up for it. The revolver is replaced with the (better) Desert Eagle and the Crossbow is replaced with the (better) sniper rifle. The Displacer Cannon is an interesting but only situationally useful weapon that opens portals to Xen, the alien dimension. The primary fire basically works as a powerful, slow rocket, destroying any enemy it comes into contact with, and the secondary fire teleports you to different areas of Xen depending on where you are in the game, which is useful to escape combat and grab a few items. There are a couple of alien weapons as well, the Shock Rifle (an energy assault rifle) and the Spore Launcher, a sort of alien grenade launcher. The crowbar is split into the absolutely useless wrench and the awesome knife, and a new melee weapon is added in the form of the Barnacle, which isn't all that useful in combat, but serves as a hookshot and is played with liberally later in the game. A number of new enemies are also added, and all are challenging and fun to fight. I'll not spoil those for you.Opposing Force is a textbook expansion pack. It adds a ton of new content, is reasonably lengthy as 6-7 hours, and well, it's more Half-Life. Perhaps the only two complaints I can think of are that the end-boss isn't all that interesting and that the whole military angle changes the feel, sort of like Aliens to Half-Life's Alien. At the end of the day, if you're a Half-Life fan, you owe it to yourself to pick this one up.

Posted: September 1, 2014
												Half-Life: Opposing Force is an expansion pack for the 1998 sci-fi horror game, Half-Life. Like its predecassor, it takes place... blah, blah, blah... Let's just say there's no reason to come to this game other than you wanting to continue your month long Half-Life marathon, and if you've already played the first Half-Life. With that said, you should have mastered the game mechanics of the Goldsrc engine by this point, and the game shouldn't take you over 20 hours to beat unless you're playing on all the difficulties. I, personally, ALWAYS choose Normal because it's not like I feel Easy mode is for noobs or anything, but from a game that's an expansion pack of a game that's 95% identical in terms of gameplay, you should probably choose Normal mode for this one. Another possible reason you walk into this game is because of the main character, Adrian Shepherd, possibly being in the next Half-Life game (♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ IT, VALVE! COUNT!), and you wanting to know the backstory... assuming you STILL haven't played Opposing Force while you're still trying to get past that terrifying Strider battle in Half-Life 2: Episode Two. Oh, sorry... spoilers.So, my personal thoughts on the game itself... Honestly... I think it's awesome. Pros: It may be shorter than the original gem, but that's to be expected from an expansion pack. And it REALLY does add to the Half-Life canon, people! I know all those people out there who are all "constructive" and argue how this game has absolutely no bearing on the Half-Life canon whatsoever. Wrong. VERY wrong. First of all, this game actually gives a LOT of information on the G-Man, who had to destroy Black Mesa, and everyone in it soon after Gordon teleported to Xen to destroy the Nihilanth, to avoid controversy over the Resonance Cascade in the future (that works out well...). It gives the G-Man a sense of purpose in the Half-Life canon and tells us about him. How he works, his dark personality, and his sinister actions. The game is also... like every Half-Life game... extremely addicting, considering it's also sort of a puzzle game... again, like every Half-Life game.Cons: It feels long and epic, but SLIGHTLY lacks in the originality department. Besides Race X, the G-Man's major role, and the ever so cliffhanger ending, the game occasionally just feels like a port of Half-Life in someone else's point of view, who ALSO happens to be another one of the good guys. Nope, you don't get to see why you have to fight the Gene worm at the final boss, it just HAPPENS. I mean, don't get me wrong, the boss is great but... *sigh*... never mind. What else do I consider a con? Chapter 4... I just don't like Chapter 4... "SONOFA♥♥♥♥♥SOMANY♥♥♥♥INGBLACKOPSANDHOOORIBLEAI! GOOOOOOOOOOODDDDD!" Sorry, that's just the transcript of my first playthrough in hard mode... *sigh*... so many black ops folk...Overall, Half-Life: Opposing Force can be summed up in 5 words... It's better than Blue Shift.8.999999999999... oh,screw it, 9/10.

Posted: October 14, 2013
												The first expansion for Half-Life, which is also it's best in my opinion.Challenging while retaining the spirit of Half-Life. The Soundtrack is also ambient and hectic.Played from the perspective of Adrian Sheapard, part of the military team sent to deal with the Black Mesa incident, you get to fight the Xen aliens, but also a mysterious race of aliens known as X. The game adds a few new weapons, new monsters, and the level design is damn good.The soundtrack is one of the best of the Half-Life 1 era games. Although Blue Shift uses the same soundtrack as Op4, Chris Jenson brings alot to the table. It easily matches Kelly Baileys original score.Opposing Force is the best expansion for Half-Life. It's pretty lengthy, stretching over 9 hours. Blue Shift is also good, but the new weapons and monsters aren't there, and the length is considerablly shorter due to Barney's story. The Half-Life series is not complete without these expansions.

content:
Posted: October 2, 2016
												Incredibly good expansion. Almost as good as the original Half-Life itself. It adds a lot of new mechanics, weapons, enemies, etc that really up the fun factor, and retains everything that made the original Half-Life great, mainly how well it immerses the player in its world, its use of environmental storytelling, and good level design.  The new weapons are really interesting and fun to use. I was expecting to have the same arsenal as I did in Half-Life 1, but was pleasantly surprised when I discovered that they'd given the game a mostly fresh, new arsenal of weapons that each fill a particular role or niche and don't feel overpowered or useless. They're balanced, functional, and dare I say, some of them are even more fun to use than some of Half-Life 1's weapons.The new enemies, nicknamed Race X, add some much needed variety to the enemy set that we'd gotten used to and almost bored of by the end of Half-Life 1. They're intelligent creatures with interesting mechanics that offer a good challenge to the player.It does have some slight cons in that the teammate AI is, well, really dumb to be honest. They often get in the way and can be difficult to push in the right direction. They frustrated me a few times as I played through, but overall I wouldn't say they were a massive game-breaking flaw. Just an annoyance.Overall, this is a must play for any Half-Life fan, best experienced right after beating Half-Life 1 as alot of bits of its story tie in with the original.solid 9/10

Posted: November 28, 2015
												I haven't expected a lot new things from this expansion. Just additional hours of duct crawling and shooting.It is true at first. You just get climbable ropes, new type of helpers and guns.However as the story unfolds you really appreciate the "second view" thing, and I'm not talking only about revisiting old locations and Gordon Freeman appearances. I don't want to reveal too much but let's just say playing Opposing Force you suddenly realize from where some Half Life 2 and even Portal things came from. I haven't expected the story to be so much related to previous and future Half Life games because the development was outsourced to Gearbox Software   (Borderlands series).Corporal Shephard rather fights than brains his way through obstacles so the arsenal is pushed to the limit, both conventional and weird weapons. Flashlight is replaced with night vision goggles. This allows to keep fighting in pitch black areas. So it is still the same 'ol Black Mesa facility environment, but minor changes alters the gameplay enough to give it new feel. Opposing Force is a very pleasant conclusion to the original Half Life story.

												Opposing Force suffers from some irritating issues, but it's a good choice, especially for 2€.[+] It's half life for christ's sake[+] It's 1,5x longer than Blue Shift and has much more gameplay variety[+] G-Man behaves in a more intrusive manner than in the original[+] It's very challenging, makes the original HL look like a walk in the park...[-] ...but sometimes is simply unfair - some enemies are extremely overpowered[-] Many weapons. Yes, it's a flaw, because there is simply too many of them. While the sniper rifle and machine gun are great, you don't need two crowbar substitutes (wrench and knife) or another explosive weapon (alien origin doesn't mean it's different thus necessary). Barnacle hook is fun to play with, but useless in battle.[-] The god ♥♥♥♥ing damn AI. Your companions are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and won't follow you if you step into a simple corridor.[-] Grafical style - while I don't mind outdated graphics, the "new" models made solely for Opposing Force seem to be in a little bit inconsistent style in comparison to HL1's assets, but it's not all that noticeable.[-] At some point in the game (about the last 1/3, shortly after obtaining barnacle hook) there is a disturbing lack of headcrabs.[-] The ending. While not as plain as Blue Shift's, it's a little bit disappointing after the interesting boss battle that BS lackedIf you played HL1 and liked it, you definitely should check it out.When buying on sale, BS seems like a better idea since it's 1€ instead of 2. You should, however, get both right away.

Posted: August 10, 2015
												Half-Life: Opposing Force is the first of two standalone expansion packs developed by Gearbox for Half-Life. The first thing to know is that neither one is a continuation of Gordon Freeman's story. Instead, each is a look at the Black Mesa Incident from a different perspective. In Opposing Force, you play as Cpl. Adrian Shephard, one of the marines sent in to contain the catastrophe. You'll be moving through some of the same areas as Freeman, but the game is laudable in that while every area feels familiar, you'll rarely feel as if you're running over the same old ground.So, how's the story? Well, like Half-Life, the story is that you're attempting to escape Black Mesa. Cpl. Shephard is one of the first wave of marines sent in, and your transport is shot down immediately. The unit is thrown into complete chaos, and no one has any idea what they're doing. After all, while you might remember the marines from Half-Life as murderous enemies hellbent on killing everything in Black Mesa, Shephard's unit is lost before they can receive that order. Shephard is simply trying to escape, but like Freeman, he'll have an alien threat of his own to deal with. He also has more help than Freeman. While in Half-Life, you had security guards and scientists to aid you in different ways, he also has help from the scattered remnants of the military, namely medics, who heal you like scientists but more so, and engineers, who can cut locked doors open.  The weapon roster has been expanded as well. While Shephard doesn't have access to the Gluon Gun or the Tau Cannon, he has a number of new weapons to make up for it. The revolver is replaced with the (better) Desert Eagle and the Crossbow is replaced with the (better) sniper rifle. The Displacer Cannon is an interesting but only situationally useful weapon that opens portals to Xen, the alien dimension. The primary fire basically works as a powerful, slow rocket, destroying any enemy it comes into contact with, and the secondary fire teleports you to different areas of Xen depending on where you are in the game, which is useful to escape combat and grab a few items. There are a couple of alien weapons as well, the Shock Rifle (an energy assault rifle) and the Spore Launcher, a sort of alien grenade launcher. The crowbar is split into the absolutely useless wrench and the awesome knife, and a new melee weapon is added in the form of the Barnacle, which isn't all that useful in combat, but serves as a hookshot and is played with liberally later in the game. A number of new enemies are also added, and all are challenging and fun to fight. I'll not spoil those for you.Opposing Force is a textbook expansion pack. It adds a ton of new content, is reasonably lengthy as 6-7 hours, and well, it's more Half-Life. Perhaps the only two complaints I can think of are that the end-boss isn't all that interesting and that the whole military angle changes the feel, sort of like Aliens to Half-Life's Alien. At the end of the day, if you're a Half-Life fan, you owe it to yourself to pick this one up.

												I truelly enjoyed this game. I feel like it isn't mentioned enough. The game may be shorter than the other games but I feel like it doesn't take away from the game in anyway at all. This expansion showed a completely different way of how the whole story could have been viewed, it contained many interesting plot pieces and the conclusion is a great wrapup to the entire story of the first Half-Life. Posted: September 12, 2012
												This was my first Half-Life game I ever owned and we're still on pretty good terms. In this game you play as Corporal Adrian German Shepherd Dog, who is a 22 year-old US Marine ready to get out there and kick some tail. With a training camp that could've ended up like the beginning of Stanley Kubrick's Full Metal Jacket, you instead prep up for an on-the-double military response call, only to be attacked by aliens on the way in, wiping out your platoon in the war zone that is the Black Mesa science facility. The mission is called off, and the US Marines are left to survive on their own. It's up to Adrian to survive against lots of spooky aliens and make his mark as a young, out-standing American citizen while escaping Black Mesa, using cool alien bio-weapons or sciencey gizmos that make you feel like the coolest kid on this side of the black stump!I love every Half-Life game, but something about this one sticks out to me a lot!

Posted: July 6, 2015
												Half-Life: Opposing Force was a surprising adventure for me. Having played and fallen in love with the rest of the franchise almost immediately, I had never gone into a Half-Life game with an air of skepticism. And here's what I think (I'll keep it quick to avoid TL;DR's):For anyone familiar with Half-Life, the gameplay is similarly fast-paced and exciting. However, I was impressed with the addition of new mechanics that made the game an entirely different experience. This expansion of the Half-Life universe boasts new enemies, environments, and TONS of weapons. It is shorter than Half-Life, but a lot is crammed into the time that you get. Playing as HECU Grunt Adrian Shepherd is a fresh and different experience from Half-Life. However, I do have one minor caution for anyone new to the series: This game is pretty difficult. The same could be said of Half-Life 1, considering they are both older games, but Opposing Force has some moments where things may take a dip into the frustrating part of the spectrum. So quicksave a lot, newbies.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2015
												Half-Life: Opposing Force -This game is an expansion of the original Half-Life. Its content will amount to, or at least in my experience, about half (punny) the play-time of Half-Life. It follows a different character, from, you guessed it, the opposing force. Going into this expansion I didn't think it would be at long as it was. So, it tended to drag on a bit around the middle. The gameplay is the same as Half-Life, but you get more weapons and other items. I had tons of fun with this expansion. If you are going to play Half-Life, I think you need to play this expansion, and the next (Blue Shift).I had one big problem at the end of the game, though. From what I hear, it's a pretty common glitch, but I had just beaten the final boss. Instead of fading away (like it should), it disappeared, and I was left wandering around, wondering what to do. You are supposed to be transported to the final scene of the game, but that didn't happen for me. Not sure if it was my version, or my platform or what. Thanks to the Steam ommunity I found a code to put into the console that sends you to the coorrect scene. :DAnyway, one big glitch near the end aside, this is a great expansion and worth the money (even more so if on sale). the story is interesting, and Half-Life fans will really enjoy it.

content:
Posted: February 19, 2016
												Now it is time to review the next installment of the crowbar simulator, the 1999 version... Wait... There is no crowbar in this game? Then how can it be the next installment of the world's most famous crowbar simulator??!! no it must be the wrong game... No you say? The crowbar is replaced with a Pipe Wrench and a combat knife? that is just great, it is already going to be my favourite game of all time *thick sarcasm*Well let's jam!//I have to say that I have played Blue shift, in my opinion when it comes to new content and so on, Opposing force is way too superior compared to blueshift//Half-life: opposing forces is the first expansion of the original game which "supposedly" flips the game upside down. Well let just be honest, this expansion is very much like the original half-life just without any crowbar and other weapons like the hivegun, some new weapons, new monsters and probably lacking some bits compared to the original game. But is it still fun? I would say yes :) Even though this one probably misses some more plot compared to half-life(Which already had a little plot) then it would  probably still satisfy your craving when finishing the original one.This game is only recommend if!- IF YOU HAVE PLAYED THROUGH THE ORIGINAL HALF-LIFE'S SINGLEPLAYER- You do not mind an old game with old "ugly" grafic, glitches and somewhat buggy AI.- If you love the half-life franchies and want to know more because this one gives some more hints to the original game.- you like a FPS game with some puzzle elements(just like the original game this one does not give you the glues straight ahead when it comes to the "puzzles" and the plot itself)The killers of the game.- The plot itself was more lacking than the original and with lesser hints of what is going on like what is the x-race and so on.- Even though I loved some of the new weapons I must say that the M249 SAW was way!!!! too!!! powerful. Either they should have provided with less ammo or something else  because even on hard difficulty it was way too easy with this weapon.- NO CROWBAR!!!- The game just like the original is filled with glitches here and there where you can get stuck weird places especially loading scenes.- The AI is not that great, still gives some challenge, but often you can sneak kill them.The Sunshines of the game- IT IS HALFLIFE...- Some of the new weapons were quite interesting especially the living ones :3 so kawaii!- It gives more interesting details about the g-man and there are some quite interesting encounters - Some quite interesting new creatures compared to the original one.- The game is really good to make a real connection to the original one, you even get to see Morgan Freeman. :)The game itself did not bring that much new to the table, yes some new monsters, new weapons, soldiers which you can "control", use and loot when you have led them to their death :P. But the game seemed to be too easy and missing more to the story line throughout the gameplay.But in the end it was still fun to play and totally worth it when you meet G-man and get more hints and details about the mystery of the half-life franchies.But if you are not a really great fan of half-life and old FPS games then pass on.

Maybe even get the bundle since it's cheaper.Half-Life IS over 20 years old though, so keep that in mind when judging the graphics. The controls and physics on the other hand have aged very nicely and are extremely comfortable to use. I highly recommend it, especially if you're into shooters.

I would say yes :) Even though this one probably misses some more plot compared to half-life(Which already had a little plot) then it would  probably still satisfy your craving when finishing the original one.This game is only recommend if!- IF YOU HAVE PLAYED THROUGH THE ORIGINAL HALF-LIFE'S SINGLEPLAYER- You do not mind an old game with old "ugly" grafic, glitches and somewhat buggy AI.- If you love the half-life franchies and want to know more because this one gives some more hints to the original game.- you like a FPS game with some puzzle elements(just like the original game this one does not give you the glues straight ahead when it comes to the "puzzles" and the plot itself)The killers of the game.- The plot itself was more lacking than the original and with lesser hints of what is going on like what is the x-race and so on.- Even though I loved some of the new weapons I must say that the M249 SAW was way!!!! too!!! powerful. Either they should have provided with less ammo or something else  because even on hard difficulty it was way too easy with this weapon.- NO CROWBAR!!!- The game just like the original is filled with glitches here and there where you can get stuck weird places especially loading scenes.- The AI is not that great, still gives some challenge, but often you can sneak kill them.The Sunshines of the game- IT IS HALFLIFE...- Some of the new weapons were quite interesting especially the living ones :3 so kawaii!- It gives more interesting details about the g-man and there are some quite interesting encounters - Some quite interesting new creatures compared to the original one.- The game is really good to make a real connection to the original one, you even get to see Morgan Freeman. :)The game itself did not bring that much new to the table, yes some new monsters, new weapons, soldiers which you can "control", use and loot when you have led them to their death :P. But the game seemed to be too easy and missing more to the story line throughout the gameplay.But in the end it was still fun to play and totally worth it when you meet G-man and get more hints and details about the mystery of the half-life franchies.But if you are not a really great fan of half-life and old FPS games then pass on.

Posted: May 23, 2016
												Half Life Opposing Force is a 1999 Expansion of Valve's Half Life, In this "Retelling" of the infamous Black Mesa incident a manmade catastrophe that took place in some vague timespan between 2000 to 2009 AD and would ultimately pave the way for Earth's invasion by the Universal Union or "Combine"  during the seven hour war mentioned in Half Life 2. You play the game via the eye's of one Corporal Adrian Shephard a member of an fictional special forces unit within the United States military. The game starts with you and your "stars n stripes" squadmates already in the air over the desert surrounding Black Mesa debating what the purpose of their deployment is only to be shot down by alien aircraft. You wake up in an infirmary a few hours later to learn that the military incursion as seen towards the second "Half" of Half Life was failing and the high brass has ordered all personell to abandon the base. You make your way to the evacuation sight only to be stopped by the nefarious "Gman" who sees to it that you do not leave the base with your fellow soldiers. As the game continues on you encounter another military unit however this one unlike your fellow HECU marines are hostile. These are the "Black Ops" as their name suggests they are a Black Operations unit sent in to finish the job the HECU failed to do which was to contain the base by "Any means possible" in this case the Black Ops have brought along a nuclear bomb  to destroy the compound and anything in it. Aside from the Black Ops theres also the "Race X" aliens a new group of hostille species tunneling their way to our lovely Earth in the "Last hours" of the resonance cascade. At the climax of the game you battle the Race X's "Biggest and baddest" member the "Gene worm" a gigantic monstrosity that according to the official Prima guide was sent to "Terraform" Earth hoewever you manage to defeat this thing before it can do its thing it exploding in a burst of portal energy similar to the boss fight of the first game. You awaken on a V-22 with the gman who promptly tells you that you have seen to much and you will be "detained" until further notice. Adrian Shephard has yet to show his face since his 1999 debut in the series and due to Valve's more recent titles suchas Team Fortress 2 Dota 2 and CS:GO it is unlikely he or "Any" of the actual Half Life cast will be shown in a future title. overall this game is one of my favorites in this series. My only wish is that gearbox had made more of these expansions aside this Blue Shift and the PS2 expansion "Decay" I give it an 9.5/10

Posted: February 13, 2016
												"This is what a singleplayer expansion should be." - MeWhile modern singleplayer expansions usually just offer new weapons or a new area to explore, this expansion shows the same game and story from the eyes of the enemy. You play as Adrian Shepard, a solider who is stuck in the middle of an alien invasion. Work with other soliders to survive Aliens & Black Ops, who are trying to silence all witnesses and destroy the entire area.This expansion not only includes the new story and places, but new weapons alien, military, and experimental. Also a new Half Life Multiplayer experience with not only new maps(like Dust from CS 1.6 :D) & weapons, but a Capture the Flag Gamemode.I recommend this Expansion to anyone who enjoyed Half Life.9.9/10

content:
Posted: August 30, 2015
												Half-Life: Opposing ForceThe Lambda incident through the eyes of the enemy Half-life: Opposing Force, developed by Gearbox and released in 1999, is an expansion pack for Valves critically acclaimed fps, Half-Life. With new weapons, aliens and gameplay Opposing Force, although not as good as its older sister, is a short and fun game to play after you’ve finished the original Half-Life.After a Resonance Cascade occurs ripping holes in dimensional space allowing aliens to pass through to earth, Corporal Adrian Shepard, a U.S. marine in the Hazardous Environment Combat Unit, and his team are sent to neutralize the situation by exterminating all life forms in the facility. This Resonance Cascade has also caught the attention of another alien species, Race X, who decided to conquer humanity and claim Earth as their own. This game is not essential to the Half-Life story line, however if you’re a big fan of the original game and are interested to see the Black Mesa incident through the eyes of the enemy, then this is a game worth playing. There are also many references to the first game and even a Gordon Freeman cameo.One feature which makes this game a great expansion pack for Half-Life is the fact that Gearbox introduced new enemies and weapons. If not for these aspects this expansion pack would be nowhere near as good as it is. My personal favourite weapon was the Barnacle Grapple which allowed you to latch onto organic matter and go flying towards it. There is also a Displacer Cannon which can beam you to Xen and back or obliterate other enemies no matter how large. The gameplay in general is the same as Half-Life with lots of platforming, puzzles and large battles against lots of enemies. You can even get help from other soldiers to heal you, break down doors or kill other enemies. The Graphics in Opposing Force are dated and nowhere near as good as those in Half-Life: Source, I wouldn’t recommend this game for people who cringe at bad graphics. The level design in Opposing Force, like its predecessor, is well thought out and goes well with the platforming, with lots of optional areas to explore.Overall this was a solid game from start to finish, however I would only recommend this game to those who loved Half-Life. The level design was great and the gameplay was fun with new weapons and enemies, however the graphics, for some people, may distract from this. Unfortunately there were no new “stand out” soundtracks in this game. Those from Half-Life were recycled.7.5/10

content:
Posted: October 17, 2016
												I first played this when it came out in the Half-Life Platinum Bundle in stores, and at the time it was most likely the best game out there. Even now, it stands out as having some of the most memorable AI, interesting mechanics, and diverse weapons of any game I have ever seen. If you enjoyed Half-Life or any of it's other Gold-Source offshoots, you will like Opposing Force. Opposing force puts the player character into the Black Mesa incident much later than all other games in the series, and keeps the player there far after every other character's story has ended. One thing that sets this game far from other titles in the series is its difficulty. There are times when playing on hard that the AI for alien creatures and Black Ops teams seems to be almost mockingly hard. Even though they rely heavily on scripted paths and arenas, the Black Ops teams surpass what any enemy in the rest of the series can do, providing long fights that force the player to both act quickly and prepare for the multitude of tricks the enemy can pull at will.The weapons in this game were also an enjoyable departure from Half-Life, and may even outshine the innovative gravity gun from the sequels. Opposing Force arms players with many alien weapons, most notably, the embryo of one of the game's most memorable alien enemies. It also adds a handheld barnacle which, while ridiculous, is used as a grappling hook very similar to the recently added Team Fortress 2 grapple. The dislocator, although impractical as a weapon outside of emergencies, is a very interesting idea for a weapon, as it allows limited travel between Earth and Xen. I highly reccomend this game to anyone who enjoys speedrunning, the original Half-Life series, hard games, or doesn't mind trying older titles.

Posted: January 27, 2016
												The main thing you need to know about this game is that it's not a simple retelling of the Half-Life chapters from the military perspective. Opposing Force is a great expansion pack which features new parts of Black Mesa Research Facility, new awesome weapons, new mysterious enemy called Race X and of course its own story that goes parallel to the events of the original Half-Life. On the other hand the game suffers from various glitches, the most famous being the Desert Eagle glitch which prevents you from firing this weapon if you've tried to do so underwater. It's a shame that after so many years some of these are still not fixed (and won't be apparently). Also the final boss and conclusion seemed a little bit rushed. Pros:+ Good story+ New areas, weapons, enemies+ Barnacle weapon (personal favourite)+ All the good stuff the original game hadCons:- Annoying glitches- Final boss and ending are rushed- Little to no information about Race XDo you like the original Half-Life? Then you definitely should play Opposing Force. 7.5/10

Posted: February 20, 2014
												This is possibly one of the easiest games to either recommend or not recommend - it is more Half-Life. If you enjoyed Half-Life, you should get this game. If you did not enjoy Half-Life, you should not. If you have not played Half-Life, you should get and play that game first.Simple as that.As for the game itself, this is the greater of the two Half-Life expansion packs. It's a somewhat short side story to the original Half-Life, following the story of one of the marines who is sent in to the Black Mesa facility after everything goes to hell...err....Xen. After the initial task goes awry, he's tasked with helping to eliminate the aliens. It's a great little expansion, if a bit short, and adds new weapon types, new auxiliary features to the interface, new enemies, you get the idea. Fantastic addition to the franchise mythos.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2016
												Expandalone: Half-Life: Opposing ForceDeveloper: Gearbox Software[www.gearboxsoftware.com]Publisher: Valve SoftwareReleased: 1 November, 1999Canon status: Canon unless stated otherwise by Valve SoftwareSetting: 17 May, 2003, Black Mesa Research Facility, New Mexico, U.S.A., EarthSpoiler-free plot summary: You play as Adrian Shephard, a Marine who's been ordered to hunt down the rogue scientist Gordon Freeman, the number one suspect for why aliens are teleporting into the Black Mesa Research Facility. After your osprey was downed by an alien aircraft, you must find your way out of the facility, surviving attacks from aliens, black ops, and hazardous environments.Full review: Half-Life: Opposing Force is the first, and most difficult, of three expandalones for Half-Life developed by Gearbox Software. Opposing Force places you, as its name suggests, on the opposite "team", as it were: the HECU Marines which Freeman was forced to fight through in Half-Life.Opposing Force continues Half-Life's theme of varied environments, puzzles, and a minor story. The gameplay is exactly the same, save for new weapons and enemies. However, what I've found to be far more tedious was the combat. These new enemies can be a mixed variation of too quick, too big, deal too much damage, or have too much health, meaning you usually have low health, low ammo, and die several times, even on the easiest difficulty. I completed about three-quarters of the game before I was forced to use god mode due to how bored I got of dying every few minutes.Do I recommend buying Opposing Force? Yes, but only if you're a Half-Life veteran. For a casual Half-Life player who cares about story/lore first and gameplay second, like myself, you can give this one a miss.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 9, 2013
												  This non-inventive game is actually a solid game if you remind yourself you are playing a very linear , half-life based level pack.The levels are a hodge-podge of black-mesa areas / zones. Most fights take place in corridor/small-medium rooms, so keep that shotgun hotkeyed. Mostly you fight aliens, as you are a marine this time around. The enemy is exactly as the alien enemy was in half-life plus a few new baddies (that were borring but not detrimental to the fun).   The level design is linear, but made intereting by having elegantly masked  the progression path with enviornmental puzzles. These puzzles involve shooting explosives to break open a new path, and/or moving crates to reach vents and other areas. The puzzles are rarely stumping/frusterating, yet their sollution gives the illusion of cleverness, which is a satisfying addition to the bad♥♥♥♥♥feeling you get from the combat.   Music is used very occasionally, often to signify an event that lacks the momentum the sudden and intense music clips would have you expecting. The rest of the sounds are exactly the same as half-life 1. Again this is a half-life level pack, not a sequel or prequel.  As far as story, you're one of the nameless marine grunts gordon kills. Thinks get fubar quick, and pretty soon your alone in black-mesa rushing to meet the evacuating remains of the marines. The story is dictated through the occasional human npcs. The dialogue makes references to the half-life universe and games without really adding to the half-life plot itself. This game can be skipped from the canonical half-life series if you only care about the story.   Its worth the time if you remind yourself to expect a solid level pack , it's just a seamless collection of worth-while (and occasionally excellent) half-life levels.

Lenght: A few days to a week. Opposing force is half-life played as a soldier who participates in the assault on Black Mesa. While playing as a different main character, with different levels and a different perspective on the plot, it's essentially the same game, taking place at the same time as the original half-life game. If you liked half-life, you should play this, as it's just as good. Everyone knows half-life, so why should I even bother going into detail about this game? Just consider it additional levels.

content:
Posted: September 11, 2013
												I consider this game better than the original Half-Life.It has far better action and has some absolutely unforgettable and infinitely replayable setpiece moments, such as storming the Black Ops encampment within the train station with your fellow marines.The level design, much like the original Half-Life's, is phenomenal. This has less jumping puzzles and irritating distractions from the core gameplay, which is definitely welcome. It is considerably more challenging, I should add; but in the right way.My overall verdict is that this is one of the best FPSs ever made. I don't want to go on for too long, and my Half-Life review covers most aspects of this game. All I have to say is that this improves on the gameplay even more and ultimately surpasses the original Half-Life in fun value.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 26, 2014
												Wow. Just... wow. At first I went into this game prepared for a shameless cash making title by Gearbox. Well, let's put it this way, it's no Blue Shift. In a good way though. Instead of depending on references to the original to add any form of excitement, direct references are minimal, but awesome (You can murder Gordon Freeman and cause a paradox, teleport to the hazard course, and uncover the secrets of Black Mesa). None of those are even the high points (well maybe the paradox). First off new mechanics: your reticule reacts to being over enemies, and a squad command mechanic to unite with fellow soldiers. Obviously the major new mechanic is the squad command, is it any good? Well... Yes, but also no. What do I mean? It is pretty fun, interesting, and cool. However it is fundamentally flawed. There are three types of fellow soldier, heavy machine gunners that obliterate your enemies quickly, medics that heal you and can fight, and defense engineers that in addition to shooting also take doors down. Well that sounds cool, but they are pretty dumb. They always get in your line of fire, you have to beg to get healed and take down doors (mash 'interact' button like some maniac), and run right into bombs and trip mines. "Davey, hurry up with that door!" "Yes Corporal" *clunk* "Davey, nooooooo! Not that blue laser!" "What?" *boom* Yep that's definitely the worst part of the AI. Absolutely nothing else. Oh, what that elephant in the room, nah ingnore it it's fine. *Sigh* Okay I have to adress the elephant in the room. When you cross into a new chapter they... well they don't do anything. No, really they just stop and stare as you walk away in an almost creepy fashion. So, yeah not so wonderful, but it can still be cool at times. So anything else new? Oh, boy is there new stuff. Sniper rifle, night vision, heavy rifle, desert eagle with laser, pipe wrench, combat knife, barnacle grapple, shock raches, spore launcher, and the displacer cannon. Tons of new enemies that I couldn't even begin to mention to avoid spoilers, but let's just say prepare to run and gun for your life. It's got new maps, but in my opinion, they aren't quite as ingenious as the original maps. Well I have to admit I love the new variety, especially the new weapons. As always what you're supposed to do is often a process of trial and error, but I as an avid Mega Man player have gotten used to that. I guess if I have to be a downer the music isn't quite as good. Overall I'd suggest this game even if you haven't played the original. It's an amazing game on it's own right, not far behind the original. I give it 9.5/10 fallen doors.

												One of two major expansions to the original Half Life, I started playing this game after the completing the first one (Half Life Source), and wasn't expecting much for this one. Well I was so wrong, as this expansion is spectacular and well worth your time and money. It's puts you in the shoes of a military (one of the "bad guys" in Half Life), in the same time period as the first Half Life, during the Black Mesa incident. Lots of action, suprises, new weapons and new Xen aliens. If you have enjoyed Half Life, look no further, this is the next one you should play.

												Play as Commander Shepard before he became an Asari-smashing Quarian-pounding space man on the poopdeck of the STD Norman as he cruises around Draenor killin' Reapers'n'sheeeeeetttt. Running around Black Mesa while pretending it's actually a mental institue, while shouting "mynameachef" while pretending you are a psychotic meme-loving chef who wants too cook up and eat everyone in his path was probably my favourite part of playing this game.

content:
Posted: September 1, 2012
												One awesome expansion pack for Half Life, letting you play in the boots of a USMC Marine. Thankfully, you never meet Gordon in-game, or he'd carve you a new haircut, Kurt Cobain style. Gameplay is made much more fun, thanks to the addition of several new weapons, including a portable Barnacle to be used as grappling gun, and a living Grenade Launcher. You may also be in command of a team, and give your otherwise-not-so-bright teammates some basic orders.

content:
Posted: April 2, 2015
												Opposing Force is Half-Life mod made by the late Afghanistan modder Stanley Kubrick.Game starts off with marine zombies fighting each other.  One marine get wrench and beat down other zombies.  He throw wrench into sky which transforms into space ship.  The ship contained Hal who would later marry Glados.You play the role of Private Joker, who is a battle-ready pacifist marine who like taking pictures of dead GI Joes.  This is also one of my hobby so I really feel connected to game.  You can start by doing boot camp with Gomer Pyle and Hartman or dive straight into action.When doing campaign you are either shot down by Viet Cong or Dutchman is pilot.  Not really sure as I am nodding to music.  The music is made of remixed versions of Beethoven music.  This is to remove need for licenses, although one track is based on Singing in the Rain.  To really appreciate the music you need to drink milk plus beforehand.After surviving crash you try to escape but end up with fight against Iranians wearing black onesies.  Most enemy and friend look same in the game.  In fact, all models are based on Peter Sellers.  The Richard Keller model from Decay was further used in Dr. Strangelove or: How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Bomb.  I only watch film after seeing final word in movie title.Some of the maps can be a maze.  If you get lost it will begin to snow before you freeze to death next to Jack Nicholson.  If you press use button on Jack he say "Never rub another man's rhubarb" before a huge one eye trouser snake try to attack you.  When you kill worm game ends.  Spoiler alert.G-Man trap you on plane and ask for Shephard.  You stand up and say "I am Shephard" but then other marines stand up and say "I am Shephard".  G-Man very confused and not know who real Shephard is.  G-Man say "♥♥♥♥ it, no Shephard in Half-Life 2 then".To play Half-Life 3 you need to enter password "Fidelio".

content:
Posted: May 10, 2015
												Half Life Opposing Force sets a new bench mark for expansion packs even to this day and is a great continuation of the Half Life story and gameplay. Telling storys and game events from differant prespectives, ephisese on other asspects of gameplay and overall improved charecter models are all what make this a must buy expansion. Best of all, its a standalone game but you'd be hard presed not to get this expansion without buying the original Half Life. Everything that made the original Half Life Great is here.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 1, 2014
												AFFIRMITIVE.  OPPOSING FORCE IS A GREAT GAME.COPY DAT.Playing as one of those pesky marines that stood in your way throughout the original Half-Life, Opposing Force takes the player on a comparatively intense journey to once again escape the dangers of Black Mesa during the trail of destruction following in the wake of Gordon Freeman.  New weapons, new challenges and new enemies with a vastly improved appetite for destruction provide a far greater challenge in this combat orientated rendition of the Half-Life experience.If gunning down aliens and making stuff go boom (shakalaka) was your favourite aspect of Half-Life, then get your camo on and fire up a cigar soldier; you're going to play Opposing Force.  That's an order.OORAH.4 subligars out of 5.

content:
Posted: October 9, 2015
												[SPOLIERS AHEAD, YOU HAVE BEEN WARNED]This is a very unique game following Cpl. Adrian Shepherd as his team attemps to mute the Black Mesa facility. Failure causes the HECU to port out and go back to base due to invading aliens that are overwhelming them. Shepherd and a few other HECU groups are left behind, and must fight their way out using teamwork, agility, and combat. <Insert story plot n' crap>Eventually, Shepherd finds himself at the underground car lot. The Black Ops are planning to set off a bomb called the "Thermonuclear Device". Shepherd de-activates it but it is re-armed by the mysterious G-Man. Shepherd meets a Security Guard and he tells Shepherd to beware of the Gene Worm that is coming through a portal. Shepherd finally defeats the Gene Worm and is teleported to the G-Man. The G-Man puts Shepherd into a safe place in the corner of the universe where "he can cause no harm". This game very fun to play, but I was ripping my hair out at the voltigores in the underground tunnels.Praise jebebus I made it out. :IMPROVEMENTS:More health scattered around the facilityTake less damageMake the pipe wrench more useful Make Black Ops assassins slowerLess grenade damage

Posted: October 27, 2016
												A great continuation of the half life saga, continuing and expanding on the story of the original half life. Keeps all of the core mechanics and enemies to stay familiar, while adding in enough new content to stay fresh and feel different from the others. If you enjoyed the original half life (or blue shift) at all, then Opposing Force is a must play.

content:
Posted: May 10, 2015
												Half Life Opposing Force sets a new bench mark for expansion packs even to this day and is a great continuation of the Half Life story and gameplay. Telling storys and game events from differant prespectives, ephisese on other asspects of gameplay and overall improved charecter models are all what make this a must buy expansion. Best of all, its a standalone game but you'd be hard presed not to get this expansion without buying the original Half Life. Everything that made the original Half Life Great is here.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 1, 2014
												AFFIRMITIVE.  OPPOSING FORCE IS A GREAT GAME.COPY DAT.Playing as one of those pesky marines that stood in your way throughout the original Half-Life, Opposing Force takes the player on a comparatively intense journey to once again escape the dangers of Black Mesa during the trail of destruction following in the wake of Gordon Freeman.  New weapons, new challenges and new enemies with a vastly improved appetite for destruction provide a far greater challenge in this combat orientated rendition of the Half-Life experience.If gunning down aliens and making stuff go boom (shakalaka) was your favourite aspect of Half-Life, then get your camo on and fire up a cigar soldier; you're going to play Opposing Force.  That's an order.OORAH.4 subligars out of 5.

content:
Posted: August 24, 2014
												This is an expansion to the amazing original Half-Life game; this game has you playing as a member of the soldiers you fight in the original game as you battle past aliens alone after losing your fellow soldiers. This game is much shorter than the original Half-Life and isn't quite as good in terms of level design and some combat situations as well as puzzles you are put up against but is still a great experience. It is also amazing that Valve created this expansion as the story of a lone soldier running parallel to the main story; it's really interesting to see the situation from another point of view.13/15 - "Good game but not as good as the original"

content:
Posted: October 25, 2016
												I'm assuming most of the reviews are made from nostalgia, this mod starts off strong and quickly ends up being a headache of poor level and monster design. Most of the new weapons are pointless and the tried-and-tested monsters end up replaced with frusting new ones. Grunt enemies are replaced with more assassins who have 100% gun and grenade accuracy and can barely be seen in the dark using your barely-functioning nightvision. Modders were doing much better work at the time with much less resources.

content:
Posted: August 16, 2015
												Half Life Opposing Force is a great continuation of the Half Life series. The action is fast and tough, the sound could be better as in it's absolute garbage, and one section towards the end will have you on YouTube hoping someone since 1999 has figured this ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥T OUT! Gearbox tried and missed the mark with this one as in it's more of the same, it had it's moments but towards the end you'll be praying for it to be over already. Luckly G-Man will bail you out before you get your prayer hands up and you'll be left wondering, is this is the last time we'll see Shepard?

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 29, 2015
												The first of two expansion packs for Half Life. Half Life Opposing Force takes you on the role of Corporal Adrian Shepard where your helicopter crashes just before you've been given orders and now you run like hell trying to escape the Black Mesa facility. I gotta admit this is a pretty intriguing setup as you now have a new perspective of the Half Life universe. The story is quite good as a whole and the pacing is nice. The tutorial, now that's probably the best tutorial I've ever played. Training in a military academy and being barked at by my commander, it really sets the mood. Graphics I won't go too much into detail but I used the HD texture pack that was included with Blue Shift and I don't mind either personally so it's entirely subjective whether you prefer the old or new textures.Music is minimal but very good, a little obscure but I like that. It makes it unique in a good way. In terms of gameplay it's Half Life with some new enemies and weapons just as an expansion should work. The new aliens are cool, a couple you get to use certain organ parts as weapons which is pretty sweet. You even get to have a Barnacle Gun which is used pretty well for some puzzles. The Black Ops soldiers later on get pretty annoying and they're placed in some pretty cheap spots you'd never react to in time on your first try.This time not only do you get help from the Black Mesa staff but also your HECU brothers. You'll need to stick with them in order for them to help you since Black Ops soldiers have been ordered to target any grunt marines in the facility. As for their A.I. They're okay but a bit static but they do the job in healing and opening doors for you.I ran into a couple of glitches like in the original Half Life but they didn't do too much to hinder the game. Should you get this standalone expansion? Hell yeah it's only $5 and you could spend much worse these days. The cool story along with the good pacing, puzzles (oh yeah the puzzles are better now) and awesome aliens to shoot makes this a well made package. This gets a 8/10

content:
Posted: July 19, 2015
												I liked this very much in the beginning. It has a great story and concept and brings cool new weapons and abilities to the franchise. However, half-way through, it gets off ballence. Enemies are over-powered and numerous, often coming at you in ambushes. They also don't explain the new species of alien, or why Gordon Freeman and Barney Calhoun never saw any of them. There were many instances in which playing this game felt like a chore but by then you're too far gone to just give up now. There is a bug that prevents the final sequence from playing after you beat the final boss (which was a complete waste of time) so I had to go on Youtube to see the result of my seven hours' hard work. 5/10 I love Half-Life but I just can't with this game. I'd rather replay Episode 1

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 23, 2016
												Half-Life: Opposing Force is an enjoyable game that is sort of partnered with Half-Life: Blue Shift as an addon for Half-Life 1. It includes new weapons and enemies and allows you to see the events of Half-Life 1 from a different prespective; meaning that you get different allies and enemies compared to the other Half-Life games. It also has unique events that occur that make the game more interesting and not seem to short, such as adding new, larger enemies and in some cases bosses, all of which weren't seen in any other Half-Life games which makes this one more original. In conclusion, I would recommend this game if you have already played the other games in the Half-Life 1 Anthology as it's graphics arn't brilliant and the controls are quite difficult, which can take some time to get used to, and it's story wouldn't really make that much sense if you started with this one.

content:
Posted: October 26, 2015
												This review originally written on May 29, 2012 on GameFAQs"Almost as good as the original, don’t miss it!"This is a standalone expansion of Half-Life. I recommend you play this after Blue Shift because I think it's better and I like to save the best for last. The ratings and my feelings of this expansion are gauged in relation to the first Half-Life.STORY: 9/10Here you play one of the marines by the name of Adrian Shephard who enters Black Mesa. You get split up from your team and the game is you progressing along fighting aliens and black ops. The story actually isn't as interesting as Blue Shift, but this has a really cool ending.GRAPHICS: 9/10Again the same graphics as Half-Life, but to be fair this was released soon after so not much time to really improve them. Plus it keeps the same feel so not a big deal.SOUND: 10/10We get all the same sound effects from Half-Life plus more due to all the new content. What few music pieces there are seem to be recycled from the first game though. There are some new voices for the guards and marines which I like.WEAPONS: 10/10Not only do we get nearly all the weapons from Half-Life, but we get more! Notable additions are three new alien weapons. One basically serves as a grappling hook type thing which is pretty interesting but doesn't have much use beyond that. The other two are useful to save ammo for your big guns, but this method isn't needed as you get lots of ammo for everything.ENEMIES: 10/10We see a return of all the enemies from Half-Life but with several more. The new creatures are interesting and unique. A certain type is also very tough and can be tricky to fight especially in a certain area with no light… Unlike Blue Shift we get bosses! There is a boss you must figure out how to get rid of much like a certain one in Half-Life, and a final boss which also requires a bit of cunning.LEVEL DESIGN: 9/10Unfortunately this game is more linear than Half-Life or Blue Shift, but still not bad. There just aren't as many puzzles or alternative ways of getting places. However I must give props to the tutorial which is where you go through advanced training in boot camp. Pretty cool!SQUAD: 9/10Unique to this game is that you get other fellow soldiers who can follow you around and do things. The only ones of note are the engineer who can burn through certain doors, and the medic who can heal you and allies. A few times these guys are used to get past a certain point and you must keep them alive to do their job. They could've done more with them, but at least they tried something new.LENGTH AND REPLAYABILITYThis game is short clocking in at roughly 3 hours or so. This is the game's main flaw. It has a lot of new things like enemies and weapons, but not much time for you to savor it. Regardless it was fun while it lasted and it's still a blast to play with the new weapons and fight the new enemies.FINAL SCORE: 9.5/10Rounded up to 10/10 for GFAQs. This game does what an expansion should do and that's keep the same great gameplay but add more content to play with. This game isn't quite as good as Half-Life mainly due to the length, but that shouldn't stop you from playing this!
