content:
Posted: October 20, 2014
												We all know Half-Life is the classic. If you enjoyed Half-Life... you may find Opposing Force a little disappointing. In brief; Opposing Force puts you in the shoes of Adrian Shepard... one of the Soldiers sent in to 'clean up' Black Mesa.  Of course things go horribly wrong and you wind up fighting for your survuival and the fate of the world.The Good:* Most of the good things about Half-Life carry over.* New and interesting Enemies* New and interesting Weapons to kill New and Interesting Enemies with.* Explore New Areas of Black MesaAll in all a solid expansion and the idea of having a squad of specialize d soldiers to help you with is always great and leads to some interesting challenges. The Alien X Race also makes for tough antagonists. THe new black ops are also a joy.The Bad* Mundane Area Design.* Bad Lighting* Disjointed STory* GimmickyYeah, the biggest problem here is the lighting. I know Gearbox thought their Light Amp thingie was cool and it admittedly better than the flash light but... it's not practically to have the areas so dark you have to leave it on half the txchuffin time. You will be seeing alot of green in this game.Also the level design ... is dodgey. As in you don't quite feel the interconnection between the areas. In short they feel more like levels and less like actual parts pof a facility in some cases. A minor quibble. Also there are a timed few trial and error sections that will annoy you.Lastly it does feel Gimmickjy. SInce you spend most of your time fighting the allien X creatures... it's actually easy to forget that you're in the same Black Mesa as Gordon freeman and Barney Calhoun. It Might as well have been a different facility all together.Out of the two expansions this feels like the most tangental of them, and the least polished. There's also not much of the story being woven into the background, and it simply lacks the pacing of either Half-Life or Blue Shift.Not that it is a bad game.. it's still quite good but it is a step down rather than hup. Thankffully Half Life raised the bar enough that even a step down is still a high mark.

number of helpful: 3 of 12 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2016
ProsNew enemies, weapons and mechanics, the game works best when it shows the advantages you have by being a soldier.Shows you a new side of what was considered the enemy team in Half-Life.Cheap price, one of the most content full DLCs I've ever seen taking into account its $/min value.Includes the same multiplayer from Half-Life with an added Capture the Flag gamemode.There are some neat little additions in the animation department, there is a considerable amount of polishment and it shows. One of the alien guns actually have an animation that show the protagonist "petting" the creature. Very nice.During some moments in the game it will interwine with Gordon Freeman's adventure, and you'll be able to see dialogue from the original or even Gordon Freeman himself from a new PoV.There is no Surface Tension-like chapter in this one which is an absolute plus in anything related to Half-Life.The Training Camp chapter is hilarious and a joy to play.ConsMany of the new weapons and enemies are re-hashes of Half-Life weapons and enemies.Some areas feel like a completely different game, pushing my suspension of disbelief that Gordon Freeman never saw the new alien race or the unbelievably differently designed areas of Black Mesa in the original Half-Life (is Black Mesa racist and only let the black guards work in one department?)The ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ ♥♥♥♥ing green filter night vision is blinding!The game quickly abandons most of its "soldier" premise after the main team leaves and the rest of the gameplay is mostly a watered down version of Half-Life, with a few new uses of the soldier mechanics here and there.The store page advertises this game like we play as one of the soldiers ordered to murder Gordon Freeman, yet we're never really ordered to do so, as the game already starts close to the "Forget About Freeman" chapter of the original Half-Life. You barely even see Freeman through the game.Like in the original, some of the puzzles are downright impossible without a walkthrough.Like in the original, it's artificially extended, with some badly designed chapters that have no reason to exist in the middle of the actual interesting chapters.The multiplayer barely works most of the time, and is generally dominated by professionals.Disappointing cliffhanger-like ending, that will most likely never get anywhere.OverallIt's still a fun game most of the time but significantly flawed and by the end of it, it's already a chore to play. I recommend only for diehard Half-Life fans since the ending has been confirmed to never get anywhere ever since Half-Life 2 released and it is really more of the artificially extended Half-Life ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. This game has VAC and it already includes the HD texture pack from Blue Shift.

content:
Posted: August 10, 2013
												Half-Life: Opposing force is the first and the largest of the three expansions.You play as Corporal Adrian Shepard, he is the closest thing you can get to the DooM guy in Half-Life he isn't as badass and well known as his friend and rival Gordan Freeman he is still awesome.On top of visiting lots of familiar places from the ridge to the lamda teleporter room you also see alot of new places you also get a few new weapons and a set of new enemies and instead of a crowbar, revolver and the two energy weapons you get a wrench, knife (which is like a faster crowbar that does slightly more damage) a teleporter, an LMG, a Race X Shock Roach, a sniper rifle and a Race X Spore Launcher also instead of an HEV (hazardous environment suit) you get a PCV (powered combat vest) which is almost the same with a few differences like a green HUD and NVGs (night vision goggles) instead of a torch which is good in some places but bad in others.IMO this is the game that made Gearbox what they are today.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												This game doesn't stand on its own well.  It's severely dated and lacks any real story, and a lot of the choices for this game are poor.  (the alien gun that works as a grappling hook, but only in specific spots - it's otherwise useless, unforgiving difficulty in certain areas, uninspired design, etc.)HAVING SAID ALL OF THAT - do yourself a favor and only play this game after recently finishing Half-Life 1.  All the experience and familiarity from HL will help this game a lot, and fills in what is otherwise a vacant story with the richness of the HL experience.  Otherwise, if you're like me (last played HL1 7+ years ago), this game is incredibly weak and leaves you wondering how there could be so many glowing reviews for such a poor game.  For me, my only previous play-through of Opposing Force was right after I finished HL1, and I loved it.  I can only assume it's because I've forgotten/lost so much of the HL1 experience that this was so uninteresting.

content:
Posted: December 17, 2016
												Very dissapointing. The promise of cool new weapons and a new perspective is well enough, but the game spends too much time having the player solve easy but drawn-out puzzles and run around boring enclosed environments rather than fight tooth and nail against aggressive enemies. Eventually it gets there, but by that point you are nearing the end. The new weapons are cool, but you barely get ammo for them and, once again, by the time you do the game is pretty much over. Most of what OP4 does, Half-Life did much better and more creatively. Some mechanics are barely used like the grapple. The trial and error gameplay of Half-Life is still here and somehow worse because now instead of platforming, you are fighting enemies that can quite literally kill you in one hit. Get used to quicksave because you'll be using it here more than in Half-Life. Overall, a very overrated expansion that took Half-Life's elegant design and did a big squirty dump all over it.

content:
Posted: February 5
												SUMMARY STATEMENT:This game is a half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥attempt to make an alternative plot to half life. Every highlight of the game is just something you saw in the original. The value of this game is nostalgia, nothing more.Every step of the way, you can both see and feel when valve employees said to gearbox developers "oh yeah and its gotta have this part here...  and honestly just model this part after this... you haven't put any of THIS in! Where is THIS?!?!"E.g. they stole the bit where you have to jump across a chasm to reach a ladder, and they ripped off the canyon jumping sequence, and the pit worm (spoiler lol) is modeled after the 3 headed beast in blast pit... you get the idea.You know how the Angry Video Game Nerd talks about video game publishing contractors (e.g. LJN)?That's how i'd describe gearbox while putting out this "gem"Every aspect of gameplay that feels even slightly good is offset completely by remembering how much better it was in the original Half-Life. Valve should NOT let their genius be ripped off by charlatans like gearbox.There are some neat new weapons but for every cool weapon added you have 1 cooler weapon from half-life that didn't happen to make it in and 4 game segments that feel cheesy, like there was minimal effort put into it.It is very easy to imagine this was coded, textured, etc. by about 15 people who spent about 300 man hours between them working on this while being completely focused on something else.Surprisingly, however, the game has fewer glitches than half life. However, it retains the worst glitch of half-life, where you are in a small enclosed space, crouched, and the map changes (and you subsequently get stuck in the floor) meaning that you have to jump a while in the enclosed space, hoping that you happen to be in the air when changing between maps.If you're not out to complete every half life game then this game is not worth itdo not buymultiplayer is abandoned (Half life 1's multiplayer deathmatch isn't, though. Just saying.) so if you want to play that you'll need to arrange for a lan party or something

number of helpful: 6 of 28 people (21%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 23
												Boring, bland, mediocre, and utterly pointless. I regret buying it.EDIT: With a push from another steam user, I will now explain why I hate this game in more detail! Wall of text incoming, hold onto your butts.It bored the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of me because it felt like a lazy re-tread of Half-Life's campaign, down to the shamelessly copying the tentacle fight from the main game (big thing blocks progress, go press two buttons/levers then press this big button to kill it). You even fight spec-ops guys again (which was infuriating the first time, and moreso here). It doubles down on this during its ending when the g-man shows up, and dumps your character into stasis.I found it bland because you play as a marine who comes in shortly before the millitary retreats. Now, if we had taken control of a marine who'd been there from the beginning, and had orders to kill the scientests and purge the facility, then THAT would have been interesting. It would have been a nice twist retreading Gordon's steps and seeing the carnage he left behind, and would have given us more insight into what was going through the soldier's heads as their buddies are massacred en masse by one scientest in a hazmat suit (besides some grafitti and idle chatter in the main game). Honestly, the story of opposing force is a wasted oppertunity (to me anyway).I found it mediocre because the new weapons and mechanics weren't interesting to me. Sure the symbiotic bug was cool, but its a reskin of the hive hand that shoots electricity instead of bees. The teleporting gun was never worth using for its secondary function, because the secret areas RARELY gave anything good. The spore launcher was neat, but obtaining ammo for it was annoying because you need to wait around for its ammo to respawn. The barnacle gun, while initially neat, let me down when I realized how limited its use was: besides a few spots where gunk grew on the walls that you could latch onto, it was utterly useless. Finally, lets talk about the new aliens, and how much I hated fighting them. There's the little guys that swarm you and go down in one hit, the bullet-sponge cyclopses, their weapons that you have to kill after killing them, the tanky ♥♥♥♥ers that you fight in dark narrow corridors, and the final boss. The final boss was the final nail in the coffin for me because, unlike the Nihilanth from the main game, you fight a big dumb worm in what is perhaps the DULLEST fight I've ever had to endure: use turrets to shoot its eyes, then shoot its portal mouth thing. After a few shots, it destroys the catwalk, forcing you to do some platforming to continue shooting it [I didn't bother climbing the rope, I just noclipped between the turrets], while also spawning one of the aforementioned bullet-sponge enemies to drag out the length of the fight. With the Nihilanth, you had to deal with the thing teleporting you, but at least the arena you fought it in was fun. There was nothing fun about Opposing Force. It had no memorable moments besides the ones it ripped off from half-life, and I had to wrack my brain and look at a few videos to remember all the crap I'd forgotten.Finally, this game is utterly pointless. I don't just mean that in the sense that it's existance is pointless, but it contributes NOTHING to the half-life universe. Whatever story or over-arching plot exists here NEVER returns in any form ever again. Your mission was never explained to you or the other schmucks you were brought in with (lazily explaining why the scientests/security force is working with the millitary, who were slaughtering them IN DROVES earlier during the main game), the big explosive that the spec-ops guys brought with them is dealt with stupidly easily, and like I mentioned earlier, at the very end of the game your guy is put into stasis because "hurr durr, that's what happened to Gordon in half-life, so lets do that too!". The greatest example of how pointless this game truly is can be summed up with an encounter early on; you come across a medic, who you need to escort to heal an engineer, who you need to open a door, and once he does, he runs in and is immediatly mowed down by a sentry turret. I could have saved myself 7 minutes of fighting if I'd simply noclipped through the door and kept going. Also, your dumb-as-dirt marine squaddies only follow you for a certain amount of time, and are stopped by invisible lines that they won't cross.And that is why I think that half-life: Opposing Force is a piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥ and why I honestly regret purchasing it.

content:
Posted: December 16, 2014
												I thought I'd like Opposing Force, but I did not. It's certainly an interersting concept that appeals to me, the chance to play as a HECU marine during the Black Mesa Incident and be on the side of the "bad guys" is a cool idea in my book, and although Opposing Force opened strong, I felt that as it went on it became progressively weaker. I think that where this game fails the most is in the gameplay. There are way too many weapons that you can carry around in this game (16 in total) and it gets to a point where either you forget to use them or they are redundant. I found myself sticking to the basic, dependable weapons the whole time (shotgun, assault rifle, etc) and there was never really a time when I had to switch to those alien weapons. I should also add that the barnacle gun is pretty much useless except for a couple of pre planned sequences where you have to go across an area using it, so that gun doesnt really see a lot of action which is dissappointing because it would have been cool to grapple up on regular ledges (not organic ones) and get a different view of the battle/tactical advantage. the AI in this game is also rather stupid, your marine buddies who are supposed to tag along with you (and offer you things like health etc.) will either get killed in about 10 seconds or glitch on a wall and stop following you. They're honestly better off dead so that you can take their guns and move along. The story is also pretty much nonexistent. No one bothers to explain where "Race X" comes from (and why Gordon didn't see them in his travels) and the same applies to the Black Ops enemies. They are part of the military, shouldn't they be HELPING you? What reason would they want to kill you for? And that boss battle, geez... what a boring waste of time. Whoever came up with that sorry♥♥♥♥♥excuse of a boss battle needs to be fired (there's nothing fun about shooting 2 eyes out of a monster). So, overall Opposing Force is an expansion pack that sets out to be as grandiose as the original Half-Life, but fails on its delivery. It's 5 bucks, so at the end of the day it's your choice as to whether or not you think its worth the pick up. But in my opinion, it's not really worth it.

Half-Life: Opposing Force provides more of the same for Half-Life fans.Pros: Story, GameplayCons: RepetitiveHalf-Life: Opposing Force follows the struggle of Adrian Shephard as he is dispatched to quell the disturbances at the Black Mesa Research Facility.  The story and gameplay stay true to the original Half-Life, though perhaps with a bit less platforming (thankfully).However, the second time through Black Mesa seems a little less exciting.  Of course, the multiplayer for this 1999 title has long since passed.Fans will probably enjoy playing, and newcomers, skipping.7/10

content:

												I don't think I've ever played a game with as much dichotomy in quality as this. The first half of the game is a clear showcase of the practice the developers had making the first two parts of HL1, and is probably the most fun I've had with the series so far. The second half is a tedious parade of gimmicky weapon showcasing at the cost of actually useful resources, and so you spend half your time with your hand stuck up an alien bug's♥♥♥♥♥and the other half trying to fight off ninjas with half a clip of ammunition for your real guns.I'll admit I've not actually finished this one at the time of writing, as after a while I just didn't have the patience to survive another wave of heavily armored enemies using a space fish's acid loogies and four points of health. Kind of a surprising turnabout considering how strong it started.

												This is a pretty awesome exspansion pack it pretty much offers more of what made Half life so great but with new weapons and new aliens a true product of its time when Epansion packs were awesome and not just cheap 2-3 hour dlc addons no this is a quality 6-8 hour expansion with multiplayerProsCool new aliens Spectacular new weapons Your ai buddies actually have decent fire powerThe boss battles while nothing to special are way better than the ones from the main gameShepards mighty rench smites all who oppose youThe multiplayer can be fun Alien weaponry is awesome but gross to think aboutConsI think this game got a bit carried away with the difficulty some of the later levels are just a pain Your ai buddies may have better guns but there still pretty stupidIt may be tough for newcomers to get the hang of the multiplayer because I'm pretty sure most people still playing it have been playing since 1999This game does offer lots of new guns but not many oppertunities to use all of them for instance the Displacer gun is like a BFG with teleprting as a bonus but I only used it like 2-3 timesNot a fan of the HD weapons pack it looks odd and theres no option for the classic weaponsSo opposing force is pretty awesome but it does have a few flaws however if you liked Half life you'll like this as it's more of the same but with new stuff added on so yeah I'd recomend this game any day the best way to get it would be through the Half life complete bundle

Posted: June 22, 2014
												Half-Life: Opposing Force follows the story of a soldier during the Black Mesa incident.  Compared with Half-Life: Blue Shift, this game is a bit longer and funner to play.  There's a wider variety of enemies and weapons.  There's less puzzles that involve moving objects around, so object boosting, which is a glitch where pressing the use key on an object and a direction will cause the object to fly away at a high speed, is less big of a deal.  But what I enjoyed the most was the levels.  There's a nice mixture of shooting and puzzle solving that is interesting and well paced.  One moment I'll be blasting my way through soldiers or aliens and the next I'm trying to figure out how to get up an elevator shaft without electrocuting myself.  The only downside I can see is that if you've played Half-Life, there are a few level designs that are lifted straight out of it.  Even without comparison or knowledge of the Half-Life series, it is a good game.  Gearbox might've not done as good of a job on Blue Shift, but Opposing Force is definitely worthy of a play-through.

Posted: May 28, 2014
												This game is for those that liked Half-Life 1 so much that they want to go back to Black Mesa. The first obvious difference is that you are now a soldier rather than a physicist. As such you have tools like night vision goggles and sniper rifles that replace the flashlight and crossbow. You also have segments where you lead ai soldiers around so they can open doors for you and heal you. This is all to help you feel like you're part of the army descending on Black Mesa to find and kill Gordon. This spin off is shorter but it still tries to reflect the first game by having Sheperd go through a similar story arc. You work your way up starting with the head crabs and moving on to special forces and new variants on aliens. You also get access to more guns throughout the game but it feels a little tacked on at times. The story also messes with the whole timeline implying that aliens were being researched even before the resonance cascade. I'd say if you are a big enough fan of the series you should play it just because it's part of the HL universe.

												Another beautiful sequel,of a beautiful game.Play as Sgt.Shepard in the mission to kill the Freeman and save your life in a living hell in the Black Mesa Research Facility.Be aware of all the Xen creatures that can kill you and your team mates,with a large arsenal of weapons,from the Wrench to the Sniper Rifle.I really recommend this for who really loves Half-Life,because this sequel it's full of references from Half-Life.8.5/10 A new airbreath for who loves Half-Life.

Posted: November 29, 2012
												Opposing Force definitely lives up to its name, not only do you get to play as your enemies from Half-Life, but there's also tons and tons of combat! That's not a bad thing either, most of Half-Life was puzzle solving and platforming whereas this is more along the lines of heavy duty survival and combat. The later levels manage to get especially nasty while still finding a nice balance between tactical but still fun. The new weapon ideas that OF offered were hit and miss though, the SAW & Desert Eagle are neat additions whereas the alien guns were iffy and largely boring. Similarly, the barnacle grappling system and the squad system really should've been more refined, they were awesome when they worked right...sadly that just wasn't too often. Although, the new aliens definitely rounded out for a altogether fresh experience, I especially liked how the story that tied into the original so well while avoiding being a total retread. A must play for any fan of Half-Life.Here's to Shepard returning for Half-Life 3!

Posted: June 28, 2014
												This was an interesting one.Many, myself included, would likely expect the original Half Life, except rehashed to incorporate the point of view of dear Corporal Sheppard.Not the case.Opposing Force includes many new weapons, textures, enemies, technology - most surprisingly, night vision instead of a torch - and still manages to include as much reference to the original as would be expected. Personally, if Opposing Force had been released as a seperate timeline sequel, I feel it would have done alright in its own regard. It's also nice to see that Opposing Force is a very clever name in my view - an "opposing force" in military terms is a force tasked with representing the enemy - suggesting quite aptly that Sheppard is not the enemy, but merely plays that role. Opposing force is also an element of physics, specific to acceleration.All in all, worth a play, but I wouldn't hype it as "better" than the original.

You play as one of the Marines sent into Black Mesa, and the game adds slightly more to the original plot, and adds more weapons to use, enemies to fight, and allows you to command 'fire teams' or a small group of soldiers.It's not as long as Half Life, but just as, if not more, enjoyable.Rating: 9/10

Posted: May 19, 2014
												Half-Life: Opposing Force is well worth the 4.99 you're spending. Opposing Force is a great expansion to Half Life 1. It takes a different approch on the Half Life series. By making you a soldier for the United States Marines by the name of Adrian Shepard. You have been detached to the Black Mesa research facilty to rescue the scientists and deal with the alien problem. Though not everything goes as planed. When the government sends a strike team to kill everyone at Black mesa including you and your fellow marines. The story is very compeling in this game really wanted to know what the hell was going on and why this was happening and as you discover more things about the story it makes it even more enjoyable. The gameplay is great to it is basicly the same as Half Life 1 so it's pretty good on it's own right. There are less puzzles so if you liked Half Life but got sick of puzzles you should get this. Another good factor of the game is it's weapon varitey, and holy♥♥♥♥♥♥there are so many like the Barnicle gun being my personal favorite. One more thing that made this game excellent was it's length, for an  expansion its long it could very well be a hole other game which is good so you get more for what you payed for. Unlike other Half Life expansions such as blue shift, you get a good game but it feels very short and could have had more potential. over all though Opposing Force is a great expansion and I recomended it to new Half Life fans or any FPS fans aswell. My final verdict is a 10/10 Awesome♥♥♥♥♥Game!

Posted: June 22, 2014
												Half-Life: Opposing Force follows the story of a soldier during the Black Mesa incident.  Compared with Half-Life: Blue Shift, this game is a bit longer and funner to play.  There's a wider variety of enemies and weapons.  There's less puzzles that involve moving objects around, so object boosting, which is a glitch where pressing the use key on an object and a direction will cause the object to fly away at a high speed, is less big of a deal.  But what I enjoyed the most was the levels.  There's a nice mixture of shooting and puzzle solving that is interesting and well paced.  One moment I'll be blasting my way through soldiers or aliens and the next I'm trying to figure out how to get up an elevator shaft without electrocuting myself.  The only downside I can see is that if you've played Half-Life, there are a few level designs that are lifted straight out of it.  Even without comparison or knowledge of the Half-Life series, it is a good game.  Gearbox might've not done as good of a job on Blue Shift, but Opposing Force is definitely worthy of a play-through.

												Best expansion for Half-Life, and here's why:- More weapons than the original HL and Blue Shift.- A few cool new monsters (didn't really like that some areas had one type of monster).- You play as a ♥♥♥♥ing MARINE and get to team up with other marines.- New weapons give you new puzzles (such as the "portal" gun).- Has a nice boot camp mission.- Has some interesting areas that explore HL's lore.- Overall feels like an expansion, whereas Blue Shift feels like a mission pack with no story and cool levels.- It's a bit short, but still you get an amazing experience for your money.9.5/10

												Opposing Force is the first expansion pack created by developer Gearbox for the original Half-life game. Players assume the role of Corporal Adrian Shephard, a Marine sent into the Black Mesa Research Facility on a “clean-up” operation on behalf of the U.S government. As with Blue-Shift the game’s storyline overlaps with that of Gordon and Barney’s, ramping up the difficulty in the process. I preferred the story, pacing and level design of Blue-Shift but still found this to be an enjoyable experience nonetheless.One of the downsides to this game is theoutdated graphics and lack of pad support for console gamers. 8/10

There is a specific instance where when you are about to leave the last part of the Biome level and you have to use the Barnacle weapon to move on to the next area, and half-way through the transistion the game hangs up without fail and the only way to fix this is to get yourself a save point file that happens right after all of this happens.Other than that really, REALLY specific game-breaking error, this has a good singleplayer story expansion pack where you take part in Black Mesa's massive error through the eyes of one of the soldiers that are trying to wipe away any traces left of whatever that one dude Gordon Freeman may or may not have done. 												Everything I would want in a Half Life expansion: new weapons, enemies and guns.(Some more creative and fun than in the base game) The dense atmosphere from Gordan Freeman's Black Mesa outing remains intact the whole way throught this adventure starring a marine on a secret mission that quickly becomes a fight for survival. Posted: June 6, 2015
												When you buy what's called an "expansion pack" from 1999 in 2014, you don't expect it to be really long. Well, you can't be more wrong.Half-Life : Opposing Force could be a stand-alone game, by its length and difficulty. Where in Half-Life you find weapons, ammunitions and health packs in almost every room, you find yourself often with amunitions depleted and running with 10 health in Opposing Force. The game challenges you more than the original, the enemies are more unforgiving and the story feels more immersive due to the frequent interactions you have with other soldiers, where Gordon spends the major part of his quest alone in silence in Half-Life.Do you want to play a game like Half-Life with a more interesting challenge while following a more immersive character ? Play Opposing Force.

Posted: January 18, 2016
												After finishing "Half-Life," I decided to go and see what was done to improve upon the original game. I first started with this game, "Half-Life: Opposing Force." And when I played it, this game was a testament to how Expansion Packs were in their day, before the age of DLC. It expands upon the original game, with a good story and plenty of new stuff to make it feel like it's own game. This is what I remember fondly about expansion packs from back in the 1990s-2000s. Maintaining what made the original "Half-Life" work in the first place, "Half-Life: Opposing Force" is a concurrent story that takes place at the same time as the main game itself.This time, you play as Marine Corporal Adrian Shephard, who is part of the Marine Hazardous Environment Combat Unit (HECU) as they move to "cleanse" the Black Mesa facility during the events of the original "Half-Life." This game does a great job bridging together moments between this game and the original, making it feel like it's taking place during the main story. Again, Shephard is not a speaking protagonist, making him more immersive to the player. And again, you never lose control of Shephard throughout the game, therefore making it be told completely through his perspective.  What worked very well in the first game works very well in this Expansion. Also, the game continues to keep the game's areas interconnected, allowing you to feel like you're travelling through the Black Mesa facility. It again, worked in the first game, and works well in this one.I also liked the new weapons in this game, a Desert Eagle, a Sniper Rifle, a SAW, some new alien weapons, and even one of those Barnacles. There's plenty of new content and new areas to explore in this game that keep it fresh.I honestly found myself enjoying this game more than I did the original "Half-Life", and it felt like it corrected several of the flaws the original had. For one, the game doesn't give you as hard a time trying to maintain the power levels of the PCV. Also, the game avoids death-trap level design as much as the original did. There's still plenty of platforming with bad jump controls, but overall, I didn't have as many problems with this game as I did the original. I still like the original, but I feel this game felt more perfected. I also liked how this game gave you more useful allies (security guards and scientists aren't much help except for opening doors), but the other Marines in this game are a little more useful (especially the Engineer and Medic), but I found myself preferring to work alone, as the AI for the other Marines makes them not at all that useful in combat. Also, the enemy variety is improved quite a bit in this game, especially the Race X aliens, which also add on to the variety. This is another thing that makes this game a true testament to the expansion pack. It's a shame that most DLC doesn't have the quality that most old-time Expansion Packs did, but this game is a testament to the expansion pack of the 1990s-2000s. It has plenty of new content, enough of a story, plenty of new enemies, and improves on the original game's flaws. This is a great expansion that I enjoyed greatly. I look forward to another playthrough.

Posted: October 11, 2015
												I remember this a few years ago when i decided to pick this up when steam was rolling along. There is a specific instance where when you are about to leave the last part of the Biome level and you have to use the Barnacle weapon to move on to the next area, and half-way through the transistion the game hangs up without fail and the only way to fix this is to get yourself a save point file that happens right after all of this happens.Other than that really, REALLY specific game-breaking error, this has a good singleplayer story expansion pack where you take part in Black Mesa's massive error through the eyes of one of the soldiers that are trying to wipe away any traces left of whatever that one dude Gordon Freeman may or may not have done. Your name is Corporal Shepherd, and you are part of a team that is supposed to kill this Freeman Character. The next events that take place in this expansion pack are what happens near the end of the original Half-Life game, and this is the part where hunting for this freeman character is the least of your worries.I think Gearbox Software did a pretty good job with this one, I mean after all, they did a pretty good job enough to where they started to do their own thing i guess. Bottom line on this game, if you crave for more Half-Life action after completing the original, this is the next stop.

Posted: May 25, 2015
												In this companion to the original Half-Life, you play as Adrian Shepard, a HECU corporal at the time of the Resonance Cascade. You try to make your way out of the Black Mesa Facility, but you face even more resistance than Gordon did. In addition to the standard Xen aliens, Race X, an insectlike species, starts to invade the facility. The Black Ops are also called into Black Mesa to replace the HECU, leading to intense fights.What can I say? It's more Half-Life! The idea of having a different point of view (Adrian Shepard) in Half-Life was a genius idea, creating a multifaceted story that makes sense from both sides. The addition of a second point of view with the expansion pack makes the entire story of the Black Mesa Incident much more interesting. As with Half-Life, the gameplay is top notch. A lot more strategy and planning for combat is required in this expansion than in the original game. The new weapons add more variety and depth to the game too. If you liked the original Half-Life, you'll love this too!9/10

Posted: June 3, 2015
												This game is the first official expansion pack for Half-Life and it’s a pretty decent one as well. First off the storyline is set about half way through the original storyline of Half-Life and follows in parallel with it. You play as a lone marine named Corporal Adrian Shepherd and the gameplay is pretty much exactly the same as Half-Life. Basically you get to explore completely different areas of the Black Mesa Research Facility during the residents cascade and append new weapons in the game. Plus this expansion pack features new player models for multiplayer and NPCs for the single player campaign. It’s certainly good quality for an expansion pack released almost a year exactly from Half-Life’s release date. If you’ve played Half-Life then you should consider buying this as you also get a decent amount of new content as well.

Posted: June 6, 2015
												When you buy what's called an "expansion pack" from 1999 in 2014, you don't expect it to be really long. Well, you can't be more wrong.Half-Life : Opposing Force could be a stand-alone game, by its length and difficulty. Where in Half-Life you find weapons, ammunitions and health packs in almost every room, you find yourself often with amunitions depleted and running with 10 health in Opposing Force. The game challenges you more than the original, the enemies are more unforgiving and the story feels more immersive due to the frequent interactions you have with other soldiers, where Gordon spends the major part of his quest alone in silence in Half-Life.Do you want to play a game like Half-Life with a more interesting challenge while following a more immersive character ? Play Opposing Force.

Posted: May 30, 2015
												Half-Life: Opposing Force is an expansion (of sorts) of the first Half-Life game. This time you take the role of Corporal Shephard, a soldier sent on a government cleanup mission at Black Mesa. This is an interesting viewpoint on the events of Black Mesa, and everything is tied in nicely to the events of the original game. For example, the player at one point is in the same room as the military announcer saying "Forget about Freeman!", and you even get to see Half-Life's main hero, Gordon Freeman, just before he goes to Xen. Although not developed by Valve, Gearbox did a decent job in the creation of this game. It's around 7 hours long and introduces several new weapons, enemies, features, and followers. One of these new weapons is a detached Barnacle, which is used as a sort of grappling hook. There are a bunch of new, unique, and difficult aliens and black-ops personnel (who are cleaning up the initial military cleanup, a little redundant) that the player goes up against. New features include rope climbing and night vision instead of the typical flashlight, as well as fellow servicemen followers with unique abilities (such as a medic, engineer, or just a firearms man).One issue with this game is that it seems unbalanced. At one point there's a short segment of dark, creepy tunnels full of large creatures which is followed by an annoyingly long combat segment. It's not like this the whole time, but some parts are too long and others are too short.Opposing Force also contains many glitches. Here's a few that I encountered:During battles, allies will walk into your line of fire as you're shooting, and then they will turn and shoot you.After battles, allies would still be firing/throwing grenades, sometimes hurting the player.Following allies randomly stop, requiring the player to go back and retrieve them.In a few loading screens and/or elevators, the player will get stuck in the floor, unable to move.Sudden, unreasonable deaths; I assume this is a fall damage glitch.However, I don't mean to knock the game. As long as you don't mind dated visuals and occasional frustrations, this is a quality shooter, especially if you enjoy the Half-Life series as much as I do! For the price, this is definitely worth a shot.

Posted: March 22, 2015
												Not as long as everyone says, but totally more Half Life, and Half Life was fantastic. Hard mode this time; some of the enemies get a little bullet-spongy near the end, which is kind of annoying, but it definitely makes the game more difficult. I gripe about the length, but it's not too short either, comparable to any modern shooter, and it doesn't outstay it's welcome. It's quite varied in tone throughout, so it never gets boring. You could say it replaces the scripted sequences of a modern shooter with masterful tone and brilliant variance in level design. Also, the GoldSource engine holds up surprisingly well today at the highest settings; it doesn't look fantastic, but if you can stomach it for five minutes you tend to forget about it. Also also if you want my advice: break every crate for ammo and health, and play the tutorial because it's funny. Yep, good game, try it if you want.

Posted: August 19, 2011
												Opposing Force is an interesting expansion for Half Life made by Gearbox Software. The game pits you as Adrian Shepard on the side of the HCEU, the tough enemies from the original Half Life. New gameplay is given such as ropes along with an excellent and varied collection of new weapons. These weapons are as cool as the ones found in Half Life and do their purpose well. New characters are also in the game such as people in the Army who fight on your side and new enemies that can deal more damage. The Black Ops are still your tough enemies but the aliens are now bigger and scarier, dealing more damage up close and from far. The music is an interesting choice, ranging from typical electronic sounds to even jazz in some big fights. The smooth jazz is odd but puts a contrast to certain parts. The ambient sounds are also good for some levels. The game does have harder fights and enemies (left me at low HP near the end), but the world to traverse is smaller, with some puzzles to solve.

Posted: October 6, 2013
												Half-Life Opposing Force is one of the best expansion packs I've ever played. Anyone remember expansion packs? Before cheat code pack DLC and weapon packs? Anyway, Half Life Opposing Force is set the same tragic day as the first Half-Life just with a twist. In this expansion pack you play as one of the marines sent in to invade the Black Mesa facility after the alien outbreak. Adrian, the character you play has is a more likely playable character in a FPS but he plays just the same. He has a whole new selection of weapons, not one being the same as the original game's collection of death machines and we get to explore some different areas of the facility in this game. Half-Life being my favorite PC game of all time, I have to tell you to pick this expansion pack up, especially if you're a fan of the original Half-Life...and you're reading this on Steam so I doubt you don't like Half-Life.

												This game is the first official expansion pack for Half-Life and it’s a pretty decent one as well. First off the storyline is set about half way through the original storyline of Half-Life and follows in parallel with it. You play as a lone marine named Corporal Adrian Shepherd and the gameplay is pretty much exactly the same as Half-Life. Basically you get to explore completely different areas of the Black Mesa Research Facility during the residents cascade and append new weapons in the game. Plus this expansion pack features new player models for multiplayer and NPCs for the single player campaign. It’s certainly good quality for an expansion pack released almost a year exactly from Half-Life’s release date. If you’ve played Half-Life then you should consider buying this as you also get a decent amount of new content as well.

Posted: May 30, 2015
												Half-Life: Opposing Force is an expansion (of sorts) of the first Half-Life game. This time you take the role of Corporal Shephard, a soldier sent on a government cleanup mission at Black Mesa. This is an interesting viewpoint on the events of Black Mesa, and everything is tied in nicely to the events of the original game. For example, the player at one point is in the same room as the military announcer saying "Forget about Freeman!", and you even get to see Half-Life's main hero, Gordon Freeman, just before he goes to Xen. Although not developed by Valve, Gearbox did a decent job in the creation of this game. It's around 7 hours long and introduces several new weapons, enemies, features, and followers. One of these new weapons is a detached Barnacle, which is used as a sort of grappling hook. There are a bunch of new, unique, and difficult aliens and black-ops personnel (who are cleaning up the initial military cleanup, a little redundant) that the player goes up against. New features include rope climbing and night vision instead of the typical flashlight, as well as fellow servicemen followers with unique abilities (such as a medic, engineer, or just a firearms man).One issue with this game is that it seems unbalanced. At one point there's a short segment of dark, creepy tunnels full of large creatures which is followed by an annoyingly long combat segment. It's not like this the whole time, but some parts are too long and others are too short.Opposing Force also contains many glitches. Here's a few that I encountered:During battles, allies will walk into your line of fire as you're shooting, and then they will turn and shoot you.After battles, allies would still be firing/throwing grenades, sometimes hurting the player.Following allies randomly stop, requiring the player to go back and retrieve them.In a few loading screens and/or elevators, the player will get stuck in the floor, unable to move.Sudden, unreasonable deaths; I assume this is a fall damage glitch.However, I don't mean to knock the game. As long as you don't mind dated visuals and occasional frustrations, this is a quality shooter, especially if you enjoy the Half-Life series as much as I do! For the price, this is definitely worth a shot.

Posted: March 17, 2015
												To start: I used to add a much longer header to these reviews, but since it often made the reviews too long to submit, I've opted to leave it on my Backloggery. Also, this review will be written as though you have already beaten Half-Life 1, so spoilers are ahead.Gameplay: Well, it's pretty much "Half Life but More," and to be honest, what else could I ask from an expansion pack? Much to my surprise, this game fixed a lot of my complaints about the original Half-Life while also not really leaving much bad in its wake. You're still blazing across a scientific complex in the noble journey of getting the hell out of there in a not-dead fashion. One of my biggest complaints about Half-Life 1 is that once you meet the Alien Grunt, you're pretty much fighting nothing but them for the rest of the game from that point on, and that fighting one big enemy with more complex attacks would be more fun than fighting more mid-sized enemies. This game does exactly that by introducing an equivalent to the Alien Grunt which is more fun to fight, as well as a giant enemy which is more fun to fight than a bunch of Alien Grunts. The two bosses in the game are also more fun than Half-Life's two bosses, with the bosses being a lot less long-winded than Half-Life 1's.The weaponry is fantastic as well. Let's just say that there's a "grapple hook" you get midway through the game which may very well be the best weapon in any Valve game ever solely on the principle of what it is. The Pistol and the Assault Rifle now take different ammo, making the Pistol occasionally worth using. There are also more alien weapons this time around, and they're all fun to use. As for the level design, it still manages to live up to the standard that Half-Life 1 set, except without Xen being kind of a not fun area.Reviews for expansion packs always end up being kinda short - and this one will certainly be no exception - because a large part of the game is still the same as the source material, and since I write in reference to the source game in these instances, there's not much else to say. It's Half-Life 1 but betterer. 10/10.Story: It's a fairly interesting turnaround from the first game, as instead of playing as the hero of legend, you're just some military guy trying to keep yourself from getting killed. The game takes place around the point of "Forget About Freeman" from Half-Life 1, including a cameo of the radio operator saying the lines from the beginning of that chapter. It's pretty cool how they kept the timeline intact for the game, even leading you to encounter the "hero of legend" at a point. There isn't as much intrigue in this game as there was in Half-Life 1, but it's still interesting to see you being manipulated by the G-Man seeming as much if not more than Gordon ever was. While I wouldn't call this "required reading" for the Half-Life series, I will say that this game does do a good job at providing a good bit of background for the opposite side of the Black Mesa incident. There's a little more characterization in your squad mates than there was for the military in Half-Life 1, which was much appreciated (also, why are all the guards from Wisconsin?). Pretty good all around. 8/10.Graphics: The facility is a lot more varied this time around, and if the various branches of Black Mesa didn't feel distinct enough in Half-Life 1, they definitely do now. There's also no texture clipping that comes to mind which is always a plus. Optimization is pretty much the same as Half-Life 1; still with the stuttering after a loading zone which is kind of annoying, but what can you do? 4/5.Sound: Pretty much everything I said in the Half-Life 1 review applies here. 5/5.Overall scores are: 10/8/4/5; cumulative score of 9.0/10. A bit of a controversial scoring admittedly, but I do just think that Opposing Force is a better game overall than Half-Life 1. It fixed almost all of my complaints and added features which didn't leave a bad taste in my mouth. Good stuff.

Posted: January 4, 2015
												First off, wow. For a splinter game, it can hold it's own pretty well that I feel that I could safely recommend this game. The weapon choice alone pertain to a variation with half of the same weapons from the origin Half-life an other half existing only within this game. The title "Opposing Force" is a bit misleading in that corporal Shepard may work for the military, but his mission objective never quite reached him. The story development does a good job at providing Shepard with a reasonable excuse to not confront Freeman or have to kill any of the scientist. Similar to Blue shift there was a larger focus on the tactical part of the gameplay, yet intriguing puzzle still pop up at regular intervals.  Thankfully there are not too many cases of if-you-mess-this-up-there-is-no-going-back scenerios, but I've bumped into several mess-ups where loading to my last save was in my best interest. I recommend as you play through that you pay some attention to details around you such as a security guard going for a specail discount with a vending machine, and a scientist discovering the wonders of electricity in a way Benjamin Franklin would highly discourage. On another note, I appreciate the detail in adding night vision goggle instead of using a flashlight, but I still prefer the flashlight on the basis that it's easier on my eyes.  Too, you'll soon notice a mysterious set of aliens that never appeared in Half-life before. In fact, I don't think that these alien ever reappear within the Half-life series again. I could be wrong, but for now there's no that I could think of. Importantly, the game provided a satisfying ending. Don't believe me? Then you're welcome to see for yourself. Chances are someone did a thorough walkthrough of the game.

Posted: January 12, 2015
												STRONG RECOMMENDATION!I would even say it's better than the original Half life. I'm not usually one to write reviews, but this game deserves one. If you want to go back and experience what made Half Life great, while also going through additions that Gearbox made to spice things up, get the game. The gameplay on hard is thrilling and nerve-racking at times, something you won't get with most modern shooter titles. Having one health and trying to deafeat invisible black ops assassins is a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ but after getting through a hard section, you won't feel dissatisfied.The setting and story are surprisingly solid. The tutorial levels set the tone through the whole game, a U.S. Marine tasked with killing Gordon Freeman. Things go sour and the protagonist, Adrian Shepard, ends up forgetting his message just to sruvive through the Black Mesa incident. G-Man makes his usual appearances, refering to Shepard as an asset he cannot lose. Levels in the game are varied, you won't get bored going through the game. There are also other Marines Shepard ends up meeting throughout his journey, who assist the protagonist with extra stopping power against the enemies or heal you up when you need it. Granted, the A.I. of these companions isn't the best, but it is good for its time, same can be said about the A.I. of the enemies. A couple of alien weapons, like the Barnacle gun which acts as a grappling hook or the Spore launcher, which acts as a projectile launcher with ammo that you can only gather from the game environment, are welcome additions to the game.Overall, Opposing Force is a game worth your time!

Posted: September 27, 2014
												I was very young when I first layed eyes upon the Half-Life universe, eagerly soaking up what was then a masterpiece of graphical splendour with a creepy edge like few other games at the time. By the time I was old enough to truly appreciate the games I grew up seeing my father and brother playing, Half-Life wasn't quite at the cutting edge, but still I loved it to bits.So to expand upon what was already for me an iconic game was very appealing. I picked up the Half-Life Anothology (which also included Blue-Shift) and started Opposing Force. The atmosphere is very much similar to the original Half-Life, but the expanded themes, puzzles, weapons and 'monsters' made the experience much deeper. The fights are harder, ammunition can get pretty scarce and managing the skillsets of your fleeting (and somewhat disposable) squadmates makes for more thought-provoking tactics and gameplay. I liked the classes of friendly grunts, each having their own particular value. Keeping the Medics alive in the later stages is a must as medkits dry up and the Xen alien forces become stronger and more diverse. The heavys and engineers too have their own role (although the latter only have certain points at which they are useful). The AI is somewhat improved over the original (or at least I thought so), and the aliens aren't simply using the rush tactic all the time. Some will take time to think about flanking and flushing you out of fixed positions with ranged explosives.Graphically, the story is the same as the original (and Blue Shift, with the HD pack installed) and you will meet many familair allies and enemies, though both have variances that seem merely cosmetic. The design of the new enemies is very much in keeping with the original, and overall they make a very much positive impact. The locales too are what you'd expect from Black Mesa architecture, with some overlap with HL levels (which I suppose are justified).If you are a fan of the Half-Life series, have enjoyed the original Half-Life and want to expand the gameplay, this expansion is worth every penny (I imagine that most Half-Life fans by now have, like me, played this and Blue Shift to death).  Don't compare it to contemporary shooters (if you are new to HL1), it's not up to the expected standard, but this game and all expansions have stood the test of time and aged exceptionally well, thanks in part to a very active mod community.Must-Buy!

												Not as long as everyone says, but totally more Half Life, and Half Life was fantastic. Hard mode this time; some of the enemies get a little bullet-spongy near the end, which is kind of annoying, but it definitely makes the game more difficult. I gripe about the length, but it's not too short either, comparable to any modern shooter, and it doesn't outstay it's welcome. It's quite varied in tone throughout, so it never gets boring. You could say it replaces the scripted sequences of a modern shooter with masterful tone and brilliant variance in level design. Also, the GoldSource engine holds up surprisingly well today at the highest settings; it doesn't look fantastic, but if you can stomach it for five minutes you tend to forget about it. Also also if you want my advice: break every crate for ammo and health, and play the tutorial because it's funny. Yep, good game, try it if you want.

Posted: July 5, 2014
												Everything good/bad with Half-Life and this stays the same. Excellent setting, poor visuals, adequate gameplay. The main difference is the point of view, and the fact OF is significantly shorter. However, you also get to do more of the same things, running around on rail, which is always fun ; killing Black Ops, which is always satisfying. But you also get to use a grapple hook and shoot with mortars at some point ! Meanwhile the narrative is quite nicely connected with that of the original and it manages to still be very fresh story wise with a nicely executed POV shift that also asks for alot more cooperation with NPCs. Overall, quite worthy of your time.

Posted: July 5, 2014
												Uncle Shepards Happy FunyardAfter the awesome Half Life 1 and the (relatively) lackluster Blue Shift, Opposing Force gives you more of the classic Half Life experience while also adding a handful of new features. The latter often work out nicely (i.e. the Portal Gun that lets you go back to Xen to stock up on health and energy, or the Barnacle Gun that serves as a grappling hook of sorts), while others could have used some polish - the rope climbing mechanic feels very akward, and the AI of the small squad you're occasionally put in charge of is nothing short of suicidal. And since you actually are part of the HECU unit you would normally fight, the standard enemy soldier now is replaced by some mysterious Black Ops that works exactly the same - not exactly a creative solution. Finally, the End Boss doesn't deserve the name (admittedly, Blue Shift had no End Boss at all, but its still a shame seeing how cool the battle against HL1's Nihilanth was).Despite of these flaws, Opposing Force still is a fantastic FPS, with a broad arsenal of interesting weapons, challenging enemies (I'm looking at you, Ninja Girls) and a wide range of environments ranging from the laboratories and deeper maintenance shafts of Black Mesa to ruined surface areas and finally the strange world of Xen.

Posted: August 19, 2011
												Opposing Force is an interesting expansion for Half Life made by Gearbox Software. The game pits you as Adrian Shepard on the side of the HCEU, the tough enemies from the original Half Life. New gameplay is given such as ropes along with an excellent and varied collection of new weapons. These weapons are as cool as the ones found in Half Life and do their purpose well. New characters are also in the game such as people in the Army who fight on your side and new enemies that can deal more damage. The Black Ops are still your tough enemies but the aliens are now bigger and scarier, dealing more damage up close and from far. The music is an interesting choice, ranging from typical electronic sounds to even jazz in some big fights. The smooth jazz is odd but puts a contrast to certain parts. The ambient sounds are also good for some levels. The game does have harder fights and enemies (left me at low HP near the end), but the world to traverse is smaller, with some puzzles to solve.

Posted: October 4, 2014
												A lot of love and care clearly went into this game. Unlike Blue Shift, Opposing Force adds in many new character models, enemies, weapons, and even game mechanics. The storyline itself is very much reflective of Half-Life, following a similar pattern and progression, even the same themes.The game is difficult, arguably unfairly at times. It's thankfully mitigated my Half-Life's lovely quicksave/quickload system, which I found myself relying more and more on as the game progressed, to the point of literally save-scumming certain battles repeatedly just to ensure I had enough health to move on effectively. I would not recommend normal/hard difficulties to those not already very comfortable with Half-Life mechanics.Follower/squad AI is abysmal. No really, it's not even functional, but I feel like this is an engine limitation. AI companions are certainly not underpowered, but their ability to actually follow you at all is shoddy at best. Additionally there's apparently nothing in their scripting to tell them, "don't shoot if the player character is between you and the target," because at one point I found myself killed by an overenthusiastic squadmate who was directly behind me. Thankfully, sections of the game incorporating AI companions are very short, rarely going beyond a couple rooms.Those couple gripes aside, the game is phenomenal and a must-play for fans of the original Half-Life.

Posted: December 27, 2011
												I love this game. The Half-life One series had plenty of great installments, however Opposing Force exceeded them all by a large margin. Second ONLY to the original (though in MANY ways, exceeded its predecessor) Opposing Force is a testament in quality game expansions. The game was developed by Gearbox and Valve and released on November 10, 1999. The reviews at the time this title was released did not do the game justice. 	The title is set in Black Mesa during the “Incident” however instead is viewed through the eyes of Adrian Shepherd a U.S. Marine, one of the enemies from the original game. As Corporal Shepherd, the player explores more of the Black Mesa Research Facility and the alien world of Xen. 	Many of the weapons from Half-life return in Opposing Force such as the Glock 17, MP5,Laser-Guided Rockets, Satchel, Tripmines etc... However several new weapons were featured in the game such as the Knife, Pipe Wrench, M249 SAW, Displacer Cannon, M40A1, Spore Launcher, Shock Roach, a tamed Barnacle and finally the Desert Eagle.	If your a fan of the Half-life series, than this is a must own game. Give it a try, it won't disappoint.

Posted: August 28, 2013
												There are some things you can never play enough. This is one of them.Building on the already genre defining work of Half Life, Opposing Force is perhaps my favourite of HL1.This expansion pack puts you in the jack-boots of cult favourite Adrian Shepard, and kits you up in a uniform that is all too familiar to the Freeman and Half Life players.As one of the military spec ops. marines, you'll see the Black Mesa incident from an entirely new perspective. So even before you exam the gameplay, this is a brilliant piece for fleshing out the story.But the gameplay is actually what makes OF work: It is, in my opinion, of a higher standard than the original game and introduces some fantastic ideas and elemants to the experiance. The player's arsenal increases exponentially, with a dismounted barnacle, electro-laser-xen gun, a teleportation device and the legendary SAW deserving special mention. You'll find no shortage of ways to splatter, maim and exact severe trauma on the interlopers of Xen !The slightly dodgy squad system can be lived with and is very rarely a problem.I recommend this with passion and zeal. A genuinely great piece of work that for me ticks more boxes than the Original Half Life.This is for Half Life fans, story fanatics and for those who may be forgetting just why Half Life is the monolith to the gaming industry that it is.Buy now!

Posted: January 20, 2014
												Opposing Force is one of my favourite Half-Life games, and is an amazing addition to the first game. If you played Half-Life 1 and enjoyed it, OpFor delivers an intense, well-paced experience, and adds a lot more to the game. Playing through the Black Mesa Incident as the military is an interesting perspective, and adds to the complex lore of the Half-Life world. It leaves more questions than answers, as Half-Life games tend to do, which is a good thing. OpFor feels very different from the main game, and plays very different too. A lot of new weapons have been added, and although some are just reskinned versions of old weapons, the weapons here feel more militaristic than Gordon Freeman's patched together arsenal of stolen guns and scientific experiments. OpFor offers a lot of new content to Half-Life 1, and is an amazing experience for anyone who enjoyed the first game.

Posted: November 29, 2012
												Opposing Force definitely lives up to its name, not only do you get to play as your enemies from Half-Life, but there's also tons and tons of combat! That's not a bad thing either, most of Half-Life was puzzle solving and platforming whereas this is more along the lines of heavy duty survival and combat. The later levels manage to get especially nasty while still finding a nice balance between tactical but still fun. The new weapon ideas that OF offered were hit and miss though, the SAW & Desert Eagle are neat additions whereas the alien guns were iffy and largely boring. Similarly, the barnacle grappling system and the squad system really should've been more refined, they were awesome when they worked right...sadly that just wasn't too often. Although, the new aliens definitely rounded out for a altogether fresh experience, I especially liked how the story that tied into the original so well while avoiding being a total retread. A must play for any fan of Half-Life.Here's to Shepard returning for Half-Life 3!

Posted: July 19, 2013
												WARNING: this review has some plot spoilers. Only read if you have played every other Half-Life game.This game explains a lot of stuff, for example, how antlions first entered Earth, how organized the Combine were to take over the world, and why soldiers suddenly want to kill the science team. You can also see the scheme played by "our mutual friend" in the background.The gameplay is almost the same as in Half-Life but it features a lot of new weapons, some of them really commendable like the Shock Roach, the Spore Launcher and the Barnacle Grapple. In the gameplay you can actually see many of the characters from the other installments. Also you can create time paradoxes if you somehow change the original course of events, making G-Man inform you about your "evaluation terminated".Also, the "Race X" monsters, even though they are not canonical for VALVe, seem to fit a lot in the franchise. I like to think that they are somewhat related to the Combine, maybe they are part of their force and were sent to terraform Earth and evaluate its resources to the following invation and conquest. Some of the monsters like the Voltigore look a lot like the Antlions later seen in Half-Life 2, so I like to think they are related.Finally, it is full of Easter Eggs and has a lot of new mechanics which are really cool, like battles from a helicopter and really long jumps using the Barnacle Grapple, sometimes not even touching the ground for a long distance.All in all this is a really good game, and I hope we'll see more about Race X in the future and to see that the Combine have assimilated them into their own taskforce to take over Earth.

Posted: July 17, 2016
												If you have and like Half-Life, this is for you. It's interesting to play as a member of the HECU, and to see the Black Mesa Incident from his perspective. There's different abilities, such as climbing/swinging on ropes, and you get night vision instead of a flashlight. Some different weapons are available, such as a pipe wrench, a knife, a Desert Eagle, and a sniper rifle. One thing that I really liked is the fact that you can lead other Marines into combat, and make use of their abilities, like an engineer's ability to cut through locked doors, or the medic's ability to function like a mobile health station that never runs out. It's shorter than Half-Life, but a bit longer than Blue Shift. You should give this a try. Also, my playtime on record is not accurate, I spent 98% of my time playing this offline.

Posted: October 24, 2016
												As time has gone on since I played the first two Half-Life games, I've felt my finger twitch with Half-Life withdrawal. I've wanted to go back to the lack of cutscenes, smooth gameplay, and nailbiting enemies. So, I decided to go back to one of the original expansions for the game made by a young Gearbox Interactive.Oddly enough, it doesn't have the stench of Borderlands covering it, despite the insane new guns added.Half-Life: Opposing Force is a new story taking place during the Black Mesa incident, only now told through the perspective of the marines sent in to capture him, namely one marine named Adrian Shepard, who also has the similar affliction of mute-protagonist that Gordon Freeman has. You go through some of the same events around the crumbling science lab, while fighting a new range of alien enemies with a few new weapons. The game functions just like the original Half-Life. Slippery running, terrible ladders, and tight gunplay all bundled into one old-school PC video game wet dream. The new weapons are pretty effective. My favorite was the equivalent of the BFG from DOOM. No matter what size the enemy you're fighting is, one hit from the gun will immediately destroy them, which will come in handy with all the new alien species that have been thrown in to f*** up your perfectly fine day.All that aside, one problem that comes from Opposing Force is that the story isn't anything new. Sure, there's some new developments that bring further light to the conflict between the marines and their federal higher-ups, but it's just more Half-Life. And, yeah, more Half-Life is fine, but I'd just prefer the story do something a little more new than just follow the same events of Freeman, only through new eyes. It's just a 5 hour long version of Half-Life that wouldn't make sense to anyone that hadn't played the original game first.Opposing Force is still a fun 5-hour long campaign that I felt was worth the money I put into it. If you enjoyed the first Half-Life, you'll still love this expansion. It's just nothing really new or inventive, but as an expasion to an original game... does it really have to be? I'm giving Half-Life: Opposing Force an 8/10. It's a great little experience, but isn't quite as great as it's foundation on which it was constructed.

Posted: October 26, 2014
												To get the most out of playing Opposing Force, you'll want to have played the original Half-Life first. In Opposing Force, you play a marine that gets caught in the events of Half-Life. Opposing Force plays out very similarly to the original Half-Life, both in terms of gameplay and story. The gameplay in Opposing Force was generally improved over the original Half-Life. However, I was not a big fan of the platforming (in either game). The hookshot mechanics in Opposing Force were particularly poor. The game has three difficulties. I played through the game on medium difficulty at a casual/leisurely pace, and I completed the game after about 11 hours. Everything considered, if you enjoyed the original Half-Life then you'll enjoy this game, and I think Opposing Force was worth playing.

Posted: July 2, 2016
												Half-Life: Opposing Force is a challenging and inventive expansion to Half-Life that provides players with interesting new weapons and gameplay mechanics.  Players fill the boots of Cpl. Adrien Shephard, a marine stationed at a military base close to Black Mesa.  After the events of Half-Life, Shephard's squad gets called to Black Mesa to help contain the alien threat.  The game plays exactly like Half-Life, but Adrien gets access to a few weapons and abilities that Gordon did not.  For example, Adrien can climb ropes and wires.  He can also use his leadership abilities to have medics heal him or have an engineer weld a door open.  Finally, Cpl. Shephard uses several new conventional weapons (laser dot magnum, LMG, sniper rifle) and unconventional weapons found throughout Black Mesa.  Notable unconventional wepaons that get used in puzzles are the barnacle which lets you "hookshot" certain points in the world and a kind of Portal Gun that transports you to Zen for its alt fire.  All in all, I think this expansion is definitely worth a sale pickup if you enjoyed the original Half-Life and want more story.

Posted: June 28, 2016
												An “interquel” to Half-Life that can be finished in a week-end, but that will prove your skills and wits. In this game you play as Adrian Shephard, one of the marines that in the original game actually try to “contain” the outbreak from Black Mesa. Shephard, though, faces his own problems as he is separated from his team and needs to find a way out of the complex, by now overrun by aliens. The game takes place during the latter part of Half-Life and besides being an interesting story to live, it also adds some new mechanics to the Valve formula, providing both story- and gameplay-wise an interesting second trip into Black Mesa at the time of the accident “caused” by Gordon Freeman. A good game, worth a shot.

												Gearbox has done an incredible job with Half-Life: Opposing Force. Playing through the Half-Life story through the eyes of one of the soldiers is very interesting. We get to see many new locations at Black Mesa and we also get to see some of what happens after the events of Half-Life.The game feels similar to the original but also unique and different. It introduces many new elements which make the combat play out differently to Half-Life such as new enemies, weapons and the introduction of squad mechanics.The soundtrack is just as good as in the first game despite not being composed by Kelly Bailey (The credits theme is my personal favourite track). Overall an amazing expansion that is almost on par with the original and well worth playing.

Posted: December 3, 2016
												Remember when expansion packs were a thing? A lot of people don't realize it buy Opposing Force was not unique in the way it added content to Half Life. Pretty much any PC game was destined to have an expansion pack that added new levels, art, enemies, weapons and maybe even adding to the story. You had stuff like Yuri's Revenge for Red Alert 2, Dissolution of Eternity for Quake, Breakthrough for Medal of Honor Allied Assault. Nowadays if you get extra content it's like a bacon skin for your assault rifle because apparently it's still 2005.

It's obviously a bit shorter than the original game, and doesn't necessarily add much new, but it continues the creepy and exciting gameplay of the main game with a new perspective and a couple of cool moments where it intersects with the original timeline. Posted: December 29, 2015
												An extremely nice addition to the Half-Life franchise.This game will appeal to both Half-Life fans and fans of more military-oriented shooters. In true Half-Life fashion this game requires you to use your intelligence to get out of situations. Even as a corporal, you outrank every non-black ops solider who survived.Is it wrong that I felt more attached to the spore launcher, who would kill in exchange for a pat on the head than I did to my soldier friends, who exclaimed "This mission is way beyond FUBAR!" on more than one occasion?  Also, I guess Corporal Shepard has training in the field of using alien organisms as effective weapons.Some very nice ideas that I would like to see implemented into future Half-Life games (take note, Valve). I will admit, the crowbar made a much more effective weapon than the pipe wrench. And now we know where Commander Shepard gets his badassery from.10/10 Would use aliens as weapons again

Posted: February 10, 2016
												An excellent expansion to an already fantastic game; Half-Life: Opposing Force shows another side of the Black Mesa incident. With new weapons, game mechanics, and areas, it's hard to find any flaws outside of the occational glitch. Although I do wish some weapons (like the Barnacle for example) would have gotten some more levels centered around them. This game has some really unique weapons. Half-Life: Opposing Force is a testament to good game design, and an overlooked gem that any Half-Life fan should check out. It may not be quite as long as the original Half-Life, but seeing as it's an expansion, I can forgive it. Take not new developers, this is how you make an expansion pack. Build upon the the pre-existing gameplay by adding new items and areas to explore. If I had to pick a number out of ten to give Half-Life: Opposing Force, I would give it a 9/10. While some glitches are more frustrating than others (like having your soldiers get stuck behind a door, or getting crushed by an elevator that was a few feet away from you), the rest of the game is fantastic and now that it's currently on sale for $1.24, you'd be a fool not to try this out.

Posted: August 5, 2015
												[Note: this review is only about the singleplayer campaign. I haven't tried multi.]So I finally played Opposing Force, 13 years after originally buying it in the Half-Life Generation pack... and it was so much better than I expected! Actually, it was maybe even better than Half-Life itself. I thought it would be just like playing an additional map of Half-Life, and boy was I wrong. The gameplay is quite different, much more nervous and fast, in the fashion of Doom and Quake. There are new aliens, new awesome weapons, and even some cool puzzles. And it makes you feel like discovering more of the Half-Life universe; it gives you a better understanding about what is the Black Mesa facility and what happens in there. There are also some nice G-Man sightings. And the difficulty is up several notches compared to HL, which is not a bad thing. Your weapons often feel like they severely lack firepower, which is really frustrating at first, but becomes stimulating because of the challenge it generates. The only flaw about Opposing Force is the terrible AI of your squadmates, and the ridiculous dialogue lines they yell at random times. But even this becomes funny after a while. "CHECK YOUR ZONE"!Bottom line: hours of great fun, and quite indispensable if you enjoyed Half-Life.
