Posted: January 20, 2015
												I played this game after beating the orignal Half Life as well as Half Life 2 and all its episodes. Going in to Opposing Force, I didn't know what to expect. While I enjoyed Half Life 1, coming fresh from the updated and arguably superior format of it's sequels made me worry that the original game's engine wouldn't hold up to Source. Boy, was I wrong. Opposing Force is a fantastic expansion that, much like the original game it's adding to, holds up to the test of time and is an absolute blast throughout. I'd say I even liked it more than Half-Life 2's episodes. Definitely a must for anyone who enjoyed Half-Life 1 and is itching for more adventures in Black Mesa.

Posted: January 20, 2015
												Half-Life: Opposing Force is the first expansion for the original Half-Life and was developed by Gearbox Software and published by Valve. Gearbox Software have made a thoroughly brilliant expansion for Half-Life which I could imagine, was no easy task, since it had to mirror the world of Half-Life whilst adding something new to the plate.In Opposing Force the player gets to see the Black Mesa Incident from a different perspective. You play as one of the military specialists assigned to located and eliminate Gordon Freeman but the main objective ends up being to pull out of the alien infested and fragile Black Mesa Research Facility.This expansion really well done and cleverly coincides simultaneously with the events of the original game. The gameplay is similar to the way the original plays but since you are playing the role of a military specialist (Adrian Shepherd is the protagonist's name), the game is tailored to meet these changes. You have a wealth of weapons and tools at your disposal with the trusty crowbar being replaced by a trustee wrench. The new weapons feel fresh and interesting to keep combat varied and fairly tactical. There is a new Desert Eagle for you to use and alien weapons such as the Barnacle tongue launcher to cling to higher places. A great deal of the weapons match what would be used by a United States Marine Corps military specialist.The core health system has been kept the same with the player having main health and armour health. However, there are changes to this system such as using a Power Combat Vest (PCV) as opposed to normal HEV suits. Health packs, health stations and PCV stations aren't the only way to replenish health and armour. You now regularly find squad mates in the form of medics who can help you out in rough situations. The medic can be used to assist in assaults on the battlefield and you can also take advantage of them to administer first aid, ultimately refilling lost health. Another type of new NPC is the engineer which is crucial towards progressing further into the game. Like the medic you can have the engineer aid you in the game when it comes to firepower, but obviously not with first aid. The engineer is invaluable to get through heavily secured steel doors as they are equipped with the tools and expertise to accomplish this. I found these additions to be a neat touch since it gave the game a more tactical feel. And since there didn't seem to be a wealth of health stations and packs, the player is kind of forced to make use of the medic and the engineer.The creatures of the mysterious and fascinating alien world of Xen are present in Opposing Force but there is a delightful number of new alien creatures for you to battle against. These alien creatures manifest themselves during the latter parts of the game and are known as Race X suggesting that they are separate from the world of Xen and are from a different world and dimension. The following are some of the names for the Race X creatures: Voltigore, Pit Drone, Pit Worm, and Shock Trooper.As you would expect with an expansion pack the game is a little bit shorter than the original but still provides around 5 - 10 hours of enjoyment with solid gameplay and an interesting storyline which skilfully coincides with the first game. This is surprisingly a very good expansion and will leave you feeling satisfied.

Posted: January 4, 2015
												First off, wow. For a splinter game, it can hold it's own pretty well that I feel that I could safely recommend this game. The weapon choice alone pertain to a variation with half of the same weapons from the origin Half-life an other half existing only within this game. The title "Opposing Force" is a bit misleading in that corporal Shepard may work for the military, but his mission objective never quite reached him. The story development does a good job at providing Shepard with a reasonable excuse to not confront Freeman or have to kill any of the scientist. Similar to Blue shift there was a larger focus on the tactical part of the gameplay, yet intriguing puzzle still pop up at regular intervals.  Thankfully there are not too many cases of if-you-mess-this-up-there-is-no-going-back scenerios, but I've bumped into several mess-ups where loading to my last save was in my best interest. I recommend as you play through that you pay some attention to details around you such as a security guard going for a specail discount with a vending machine, and a scientist discovering the wonders of electricity in a way Benjamin Franklin would highly discourage. On another note, I appreciate the detail in adding night vision goggle instead of using a flashlight, but I still prefer the flashlight on the basis that it's easier on my eyes.  Too, you'll soon notice a mysterious set of aliens that never appeared in Half-life before. In fact, I don't think that these alien ever reappear within the Half-life series again. I could be wrong, but for now there's no that I could think of. Importantly, the game provided a satisfying ending. Don't believe me? Then you're welcome to see for yourself. Chances are someone did a thorough walkthrough of the game.
